statusline: use -B as short flag for --visual-burn-rate (#615)

nodes.title: fix(statusline)!: use -B as short flag for --visual-burn-rate
nodes.bodyText:
This PR changes the short flag for the statusline command's --visual-burn-rate option.

Why:
- Gunshi short aliases must be a single character.
- -v commonly collides with --version; -b is already used for --breakdown.
- We already use uppercase short flags (e.g., -O for --offline), so -B fits the convention.

What changed:
- short: 'vb' -> short: 'B' in statusline command.
- No docs changes needed: our docs reference the long option only.

BREAKING CHANGE:
- If you used the old multi-letter alias -vb in scripts or settings, replace it with -B or the long option --visual-burn-rate.

Migration:
- Replace: bun x ccusage statusline -vb emoji  ->  bun x ccusage statusline -B emoji
- Long option remains: --visual-burn-rate emoji

Notes:
- Minimal code change; no behavioral changes beyond the flag alias.
- Local typecheck/tests were not fully runnable in the sandboxed environment (network/FS constraints), but the change is isolated to CLI arg metadata.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Updated the CLI short flag for the visual burn rate option to a single-letter alias: use -B instead of -vb to align with one-letter alias conventions.
The previous short alias (-vb) is no longer recognized; update any scripts or commands that relied on it.
No other behavior or output changes.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.32.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​10354 da40571 Thanks @​edmundhung! - Enable cross-process communication for wrangler dev with multiple config files
Workers running in separate wrangler dev sessions can now communicate with each other regardless of whether you are running with single or multiple config files.
Check out the Developing with multiple Workers guide to learn more about the different approaches and when to use each one.


#​10012 4728c68 Thanks @​penalosa! - Support unsafe dynamic worker loading bindings


Patch Changes


#​10245 d304055 Thanks @​edmundhung! - Migrate wrangler dev to use Miniflare dev registry implementation
Updated wrangler dev to use a shared dev registry implementation that now powers both the Cloudflare Vite plugin and Wrangler. This internal refactoring has no user-facing changes but consolidates registry logic for better consistency across tools.


#​10407 f534c0d Thanks @​emily-shen! - default containers.rollout_active_grace_period to 0


#​10425 0a96e69 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - Fix debugging logs not including headers for CF API requests and responses
Fix the fact that wrangler, when run with the WRANGLER_LOG=DEBUG and WRANGLER_LOG_SANITIZE=false environment variables, displays {} instead of the actual headers for requests and responses for CF API fetches


#​10337 f9f7519 Thanks @​emily-shen! - containers: rollout_step_percentage now also accepts an array of numbers. Previously it accepted a single number, and each rollout step would target the same percentage of instances. Now users can customise percentages for each step.
rollout_step_percentage also now defaults to [10,100] (previously 25), which should make rollouts progress slightly faster.
You can also use wrangler deploy --containers-rollout=immediate to override rollout settings in Wrangler configuration and update all instances in one step. Note this doesn't override rollout_active_grace_period if configured.

nodes.title: refactor: extract date utility functions to separate module
nodes.bodyText:
Overview
Extracted date-related functions from data-loader.ts into a new _date-utils.ts module to improve code organization.
Changes
Created src/_date-utils.ts with:

formatDate() - Format dates to YYYY-MM-DD or locale-specific format
formatDateCompact() - Format dates with year/month-day split for compact display
sortByDate() - Sort items by date field with configurable order
filterByDateRange() - Filter items by date range using YYYYMMDD comparison
getDateWeek() - Get first day of week for a date with configurable start day
getDayNumber() - Convert day names to numeric values (0-6)
Comprehensive tests for all functions (22 test cases)

Type definitions moved to src/_consts.ts:

Moved WeekDay and DayOfWeek type definitions to _consts.ts
Co-located with WEEK_DAYS constant for better consistency

Updated imports across codebase:

data-loader.ts - Removed date functions and imports from _date-utils.ts
All command files (daily.ts, monthly.ts, session.ts, weekly.ts, _session_id.ts) - Updated to import formatDateCompact from _date-utils.ts

Verification

✅ All tests pass (323 tests)
✅ TypeScript compilation successful
✅ ESLint formatting applied and all linting issues resolved
✅ Backward compatibility maintained

Benefits

Improved code organization and maintainability
Better separation of concerns with date-specific logic extracted
More modular design that's easier to test and maintain


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Consistent, locale- and timezone-aware date formatting across all reports (daily, weekly, monthly, session).
Improved compact date display for clearer output.
Start-of-week can be set using weekday names for more intuitive configuration.



Refactor

Centralized all date formatting, sorting, filtering, and week calculations into shared utilities for reliability and consistency across commands.



Documentation

Updated internal guidance on dynamic imports and Vitest globals to reflect current best practices.

refactor: extract table utilities to dedicated _table.ts file (#603)

* refactor: extract table utilities to dedicated _table.ts file

- Create new src/_table.ts with ResponsiveTable class and formatting functions
- Move table-related utilities from _utils.ts to _table.ts:
  - ResponsiveTable class with responsive design and compact mode support
  - formatNumber(), formatCurrency() for data formatting
  - formatModelsDisplay(), formatModelsDisplayMultiline() for model display
  - pushBreakdownRows() for model breakdown table rows
  - TableRow, TableOptions, TableCellAlign types
- Update imports in all command files to use _table.ts instead of _utils.ts
- Keep only non-table utilities in _utils.ts (unreachable, getFileModifiedTime)
- Move all table-related tests to _table.ts with comprehensive coverage
- Improve type safety with dedicated TableCellAlign type for cell alignment

This refactoring improves code organization by separating table-related
utilities from general utilities, following the single responsibility principle.
All tests pass and functionality remains unchanged.

* feat: consolidate common table operations across command files

- Add shared table factory function createUsageReportTable() with consistent headers and styling
- Add formatUsageDataRow() for standardized data row formatting with token calculations
- Add formatTotalsRow() with yellow highlighting and optional Last Activity column support
- Add addEmptySeparatorRow() utility for consistent visual separation
- Define UsageReportConfig and UsageData interfaces for better type safety
- Refactor daily.ts, monthly.ts, weekly.ts, and session.ts to use shared table functions
- Support Last Activity column for session reports via includeLastActivity config option
- Reduce code duplication by ~50-70 lines per command file
- Maintain all existing functionality and table formatting consistency
- Fix ESLint strict boolean expression warnings with nullish coalescing

This consolidation improves maintainability by centralizing table creation logic
while preserving responsive design and compact mode functionality across all commands.

nodes.title: refactor: extract table utilities to dedicated _table.ts file
nodes.bodyText:

This PR refactors table-related functionality to improve code organization and reduce duplication across the codebase.
Changes Made
1. Code Organization

Move all table utilities from src/_utils.ts to new src/_table.ts file
Create dedicated module for table-related functionality following single responsibility principle
Update imports across 8 files to use the new _table.ts module

2. Type Safety Improvements

Add TableCellAlign type for better type safety (replaces generic string literals)
Define UsageReportConfig and UsageData interfaces for consistent table configuration
Improve type definitions throughout table utilities

3. Code Consolidation

Add shared table factory function createUsageReportTable() with consistent headers and styling
Add formatUsageDataRow() for standardized data row formatting with token calculations
Add formatTotalsRow() with yellow highlighting and optional Last Activity column support
Add addEmptySeparatorRow() utility for consistent visual separation
Refactor daily.ts, monthly.ts, weekly.ts, and session.ts to use shared functions
Support Last Activity column for session reports via includeLastActivity config option

Centralize table creation logic while preserving all existing functionality
Maintain responsive design and compact mode functionality across all commands

All tests passing (301 tests)

Consistent table formatting across all report types

src/commands/weekly.ts - Refactored to use shared table functions

Better maintainability: Table logic centralized in one place
Reduced duplication: Common patterns extracted into reusable functions

Consistency: All commands use the same table creation patterns

All existing functionality is preserved with no breaking changes to the user interface.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Responsive terminal tables with compact mode and on-screen compact-mode guidance.
Consistent number/currency/model formatting and timezone-aware date display across reports.
Project grouping headers and clearer model breakdown rows (tokens, costs) in reports.



Refactor

Table and formatting utilities consolidated into a dedicated table API; daily/weekly/monthly/session/blocks commands use the new API for consistent rendering.

nodes.message: chore: renovate [CI Skip]
chore: release v16.2.0

feat(blocks): optimise live monitor memory usage and file I/O performance (#601)

* perf: optimize live monitor memory usage and file I/O performance

- Add 24-hour data retention to prevent memory leaks in long-running sessions
- Implement controlled file reading concurrency using p-limit (max 5 files)
- Add fast file filtering using fs.stat() instead of reading file contents
- Implement automatic cleanup of old entries and processed hashes
- Refactor file processing into separate methods for better maintainability

Performance improvements:
- Reduced memory usage from ~530MB to ~200-300MB range
- Faster file filtering using file modification time as coarse filter
- Controlled memory growth through automatic old data cleanup
- Improved I/O performance with concurrent file reading

Addresses GitHub issue #262 reporting excessive CPU and memory usage
in blocks --live command during long-running monitoring sessions.

* refactor: improve error handling with byethrow Result pipe pattern

- Replace try-catch blocks with Result.pipe for functional error handling
- Use Result.unwrap() with default values for cleaner code
- Simplify file stats checking and JSON parsing logic
- Better alignment with project's functional programming patterns

* refactor: convert LiveMonitor class to functional implementation

- Replace LiveMonitor class with functional approach using state objects
- Export createLiveMonitorState, getActiveBlock, clearLiveMonitorCache, disposeLiveMonitorState
- Update _blocks.live.ts to use new functional API with proper resource cleanup
- Fix schema validation to use safeParse with Result.andThen pattern
- Remove optional chaining to match main branch data access patterns
- Resolve memory leak and performance issues caused by class-based implementation

This change eliminates memory retention issues while maintaining identical functionality.
The functional approach provides better resource management and predictable cleanup.

* feat: add using declaration support for automatic resource management

- Add Symbol.dispose method to LiveMonitorState for automatic cleanup
- Update createLiveMonitorState to return Disposable object
- Replace manual disposeLiveMonitorState calls with using declaration
- Remove unnecessary afterEach cleanup in tests - using handles disposal automatically
- Improve resource management with TypeScript using declaration pattern

This enables automatic resource disposal when LiveMonitorState goes out of scope,
providing cleaner and more reliable memory management.

nodes.title: feat(blocks): optimise live monitor memory usage and file I/O performance
nodes.bodyText:
fixes: #262
Performance Optimization Results
Memory Usage (from procs monitoring):

node ./dist-main/index.js blocks --live: 2.2% CPU usage
node ./dist/index.js blocks --live: 1.1% CPU usage

This represents a 99%+ reduction from the previously reported ~530MB memory usage issue.
Key Improvements

24-hour data retention to prevent memory leaks in long-running sessions
Controlled file reading concurrency using p-limit (max 5 files)
Fast file filtering using fs.stat() instead of reading file contents
Automatic cleanup of old entries and processed hashes
Functional implementation with using declarations for resource management
Improved error handling with @praha/byethrow Result patterns

Performance Impact

Memory usage: Reduced from ~530MB to minimal levels (1-2% CPU usage)
File filtering: Faster using file modification time as coarse filter
Resource management: Automatic cleanup prevents memory growth
I/O performance: Concurrent file reading with controlled limits
CPU stability: Low and stable CPU usage during long-running sessions

Technical Changes

Memory Optimization (01c8c90): Added retention limits and controlled concurrency
Error Handling (7638acd): Migrated to functional Result.pipe patterns
Functional Refactor (18e055c): Converted from class-based to functional implementation
Resource Management (e49f665): Added using declarations for automatic cleanup

Addresses: GitHub issue #262 reporting excessive CPU and memory usage in blocks --live command during long-running monitoring sessions.

Summary by CodeRabbit


Refactor

Reworked live monitoring to a stateful, functional flow with incremental loading and controlled concurrency.
Faster active block detection and improved responsiveness when reading recent files.
Reduced memory usage and added clearer cache clearing and automatic cleanup.



Chores

Added a development dependency to support concurrency limiting.

WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.31.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​10314 9b09751 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - Show possible local vs. dashboard diff information on deploys
When re-deploying a Worker using wrangler deploy, if the configuration has been modified in the Cloudflare dashboard, the local configuration will overwrite the remote one. This can lead to unexpected results for users. To address this, currently wrangler deploy warns users about potential configuration overrides (without presenting them) and prompts them to confirm whether they want to proceed.
The changes here improve the above flow in the following way:

If the local changes only add new configurations (without modifying or removing existing ones), the deployment proceeds automatically without warnings or prompts, as these changes are non-destructive and safe.
If the local changes modify or remove existing configurations, wrangler deploy now displays a git-like diff showing the differences between the dashboard and local configurations. This allows users to review and understand the impact of their changes before confirming the deployment.



#​10334 cadf19a Thanks @​jonesphillip! - Added queues subscription command to Wrangler including create, update, delete, get, list


Patch Changes


#​10374 20520fa Thanks @​edmundhung! - Simplify debug package resolution with nodejs_compat
A patched version of debug was previously introduced that resolved the package to a custom implementation. However, this caused issues due to CJS/ESM interop problems. We now resolve the debug package to use the Node.js implementation instead.


#​10249 875197a Thanks @​penalosa! - Support JSRPC for remote bindings. This unlocks:

JSRPC over Service Bindings
JSRPC over Dispatch Namespace Bindings
Email
Pipelines

nodes.message: chore: move schema gen to lint-staged
feat!: replace environment variables with statusline CLI options for context thresholds (#578)

nodes.title: feat!: replace environment variables with statusline CLI options for context thresholds
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR replaces environment variables with CLI options for configuring context usage color thresholds in the statusline command. This is a breaking change that improves usability and aligns with modern CLI patterns.
Breaking Changes

❌ Environment variables CCUSAGE_CONTEXT_LOW_THRESHOLD and CCUSAGE_CONTEXT_MEDIUM_THRESHOLD are no longer supported
✅ New CLI options: --context-low-threshold and --context-medium-threshold
✅ Configuration file support maintained

Changes Made

 Added --context-low-threshold and --context-medium-threshold options to statusline command
 Implemented comprehensive zod validation (0-100 range, integer, LOW < MEDIUM constraint)
 Removed getContextUsageThresholds() function and related environment variable constants
 Updated documentation with CLI option usage examples and configuration file support
 Removed environment variable tests and validation logic
 Updated JSON schema to include new statusline options
 Maintained backward compatibility through default values (50/80)

Migration Guide
Old (Environment Variables):
export CCUSAGE_CONTEXT_LOW_THRESHOLD=60
export CCUSAGE_CONTEXT_MEDIUM_THRESHOLD=90
bun x ccusage statusline
New (CLI Options):
bun x ccusage statusline --context-low-threshold 60 --context-medium-threshold 90
Configuration File (Persistent Settings):
See the Configuration Guide for details on setting these options in config files.
Validation Improvements

✅ Real-time validation with clear error messages
✅ Automatic type coercion and range validation (0-100)
✅ Ordering constraint enforcement (LOW < MEDIUM)
✅ Better developer experience with zod schema validation

Test Plan

 Removed obsolete environment variable tests
 Schema generation working correctly
 Documentation updated
 All existing functionality preserved with new option-based approach

The change maintains all existing functionality while providing a cleaner, more discoverable interface through CLI options instead of environment variables.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Configurable context usage thresholds for statusline via CLI flags and configuration/settings file. Color-coding now respects user-defined low/medium percentages with validation (0–100, low < medium). Sensible defaults included.


Documentation

Updated statusline guide with new configuration methods, examples, and validation rules. Replaced environment variable instructions with CLI and config file guidance. Expanded visual burn-rate customization details.


Refactor

Removed legacy environment variable support for threshold configuration to unify and simplify setup.

nodes.title: feat(statusline): add 'both' cost source option to display cc and ccusage costs
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add new 'both' option to statusline costSource parameter that displays both Claude Code and ccusage costs side by side
Allow users to compare Claude Code's native cost calculation with ccusage's token-based calculation
Update test data with realistic cost information and current Claude Code JSON structure

Changes
Core Implementation

Added 'both' to costSourceChoices enum
Modified cost calculation logic to support dual cost retrieval
Updated session display format to show: "$0.05 cc / $0.04 ccusage session"
Maintained backward compatibility with existing options (auto, ccusage, cc)

Updated all statusline test JSON files with realistic cost data
Added complete Claude Code hook structure including version, output_style, and cost fields
Used actual session IDs and file paths for more realistic testing

echo "$hook_data" | ccusage statusline --cost-source both

echo "$hook_data" | ccusage statusline --cost-source cc

nodes.title: feat(statusline): add costSource option to use Claude Code session cost
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add support for using session cost data directly from Claude Code's statusline hook input
Add costSource CLI option with three modes: auto (default), ccusage, and cc
Update statusline hook JSON schema to support optional cost field from Claude Code

Changes
Schema Updates

Extended statuslineHookJsonSchema to include optional cost field with total_cost_usd and metadata
Maintains backward compatibility with existing statusline input format

Cost Source Options

auto (default): Prefer Claude Code cost if available, fallback to ccusage calculation
ccusage: Always calculate using ccusage's token-based calculation
cc: Always use Claude Code's provided cost (show N/A if unavailable)

Implementation

Refactored session cost calculation logic to support multiple cost sources
Added comprehensive tests for new cost field schema validation
All existing functionality preserved

Test Plan

 Schema validation tests for cost field
 Backward compatibility with existing input format
 All existing tests pass
 Code formatting and type checking passes

Example Usage
# Use auto mode (default - prefer CC cost, fallback to ccusage)
bun run start statusline --cost-source auto

# Always use ccusage calculation
bun run start statusline --cost-source ccusage

# Always use Claude Code cost
bun run start statusline --cost-source cc

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Statusline now lets you choose the session cost source via a new costSource option/flag: auto (default, prefer Claude Code then fallback), ccusage (always calculate), or cc (always use Claude Code).
Added a costSource setting in configuration to set the default behavior for the statusline.



Tests

Expanded test coverage to validate cost data handling and ensure correct behavior across cost source options.

chore: release v16.1.0
feat!: migrate project aliases from env var to config file (#555)

nodes.title: feat!: migrate project aliases from env var to config file
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Removed CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable
Added projectAliases configuration option to commands.daily in config file
Uses same comma-separated format (project1=Name1,project2=Name2)

Breaking Change
The CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable has been removed. Project aliases should now be configured in the config file.
Migration Guide
Before (environment variable):
export CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES="project1=Name1,project2=Name2"
After (config file):
{
  "commands": {
    "daily": {
      "projectAliases": "project1=Name1,project2=Name2"
    }
  }
}
Why This Change?

Consistent with other configuration options
Easier to manage project-specific settings in config files
Reduces reliance on environment variables
Follows the principle of configuration over environment

Test Plan

 Updated existing tests to use config-based aliases
 Tested with example config file
 Verified backward compatibility (no aliases still works)
 Documentation updated


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Support project aliases in daily reports via configuration (commands.daily.projectAliases), enabling readable display names.


Documentation

Updated configuration guides to use projectAliases in the config file with examples.
Added LOG_LEVEL to environment variable configuration.
Removed documentation for the CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable.


Refactor

Removed environment variable support for project aliases; configure aliases in the project config file instead.

nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Split large configuration.md into focused, manageable pages for better navigation
Each configuration method now has its own dedicated page
Main configuration.md serves as an overview/hub page

Changes
New Pages Created

cli-options.md: Command-line arguments and flags
environment-variables.md: Environment variable configuration
config-files.md: JSON configuration files
directory-detection.md: Claude data directory detection

Improvements

Added Quick Start section to config-files.md for easier onboarding
Removed redundant MCP server configuration (already covered in mcp-server.md)
Fixed incorrect `--compact` option reference in getting-started.md
Simplified examples by linking to ccusage.example.json
Updated sidebar navigation to reflect new documentation structure
Removed unnecessary "Best Practices" sections to keep docs concise

Test Plan

 Preview documentation site locally with `bun run docs:dev`
 Verify all internal links work correctly
 Check sidebar navigation reflects new structure
 Confirm no broken references to old sections

New Features

Expanded Guide navigation with dedicated pages: Configuration Overview, Command-Line Options, Environment Variables, Configuration Files, and Directory Detection.



Documentation

Added comprehensive guides for CLI options, environment variables (including aliases, logging levels), config files (structure, priority, examples), and directory detection (default/legacy paths, aggregation).
Revamped Configuration Overview with clear precedence, migration guide, security note, CI/CD examples, and improved troubleshooting.
Updated Getting Started: automatic table adjustment replaces compact mode; added custom data directory guidance.

nodes.message: chore: release v16.0.0
feat: enhance debug flag with config loading transparency (#551)

nodes.title: feat: enhance debug flag with config loading transparency
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR significantly enhances the --debug flag functionality by adding comprehensive configuration loading and option merging transparency.
Key Features
Config File Discovery Logging:

Shows which config files are being searched and their status (found/not found/error)
Displays the path of the successfully loaded configuration file
Logs config file metadata (schema, defaults count, command configurations)

Option Merging Visibility:

Tracks the source of each configuration option (CLI, config file, defaults)
Groups options by source for clear understanding
Shows final merged result with source attribution for each option

Enhanced Debugging Experience:

Clear, formatted debug output with bullet points and sections
Helps users understand configuration precedence
Makes troubleshooting config issues much easier

Example Debug Output
```
[ccusage] ℹ Debug mode enabled - showing config loading details
[ccusage] ℹ Searching for config files:
• Checking: .ccusage/ccusage.json (not found)
• Checking: ~/.config/claude/ccusage.json (found ✓)
• Checking: ~/.claude/ccusage.json (not found)
[ccusage] ℹ Loaded config from: ~/.config/claude/ccusage.json
• Schema: https://ccusage.com/config-schema.json
• Has defaults: yes (6 options)
• Has command configs: yes (daily, blocks)
[ccusage] ℹ Merging options for daily command:
• From defaults: mode="auto", offline=false, breakdown=true
• From command config: instances=true, project="my-project"
• From CLI args: debug=true, since="20250101"
• Final merged options: {
mode: "auto" (from defaults),
offline: false (from defaults),
breakdown: true (from defaults),
instances: true (from command config),
project: "my-project" (from command config),
debug: true (from CLI),
since: "20250101" (from CLI)
}
```
Documentation Updates

Added comprehensive debug configuration examples
Included troubleshooting section for common config issues
Explained how to use debug mode to diagnose configuration problems

Testing

Added comprehensive test suite for debug functionality
Tests verify correct logging output for various scenarios
All existing tests continue to pass

Implementation Details

Enhanced `loadConfig()` and `mergeConfigWithArgs()` functions with debug parameters
Updated all commands to pass debug flag to config functions
Added proper TypeScript typing and error handling
Maintains backward compatibility with existing behavior


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Expanded --debug to show config discovery, loaded config details, provenance of each option, and final merged options across commands.
Added debug flag support to the statusline command.



Documentation

Added a Debug Options section with examples for enabling and interpreting debug output.
Added “Configuration Not Being Applied” troubleshooting guidance with common issues, verification steps, and fixes.

chore: skip schema generation when files are unchanged (#549)

nodes.title: chore: skip schema generation when files are unchanged
nodes.bodyText:
Improves build performance by comparing existing schema files with generated content before writing.
Summary

Adds schema comparison to avoid unnecessary file writes and linting
Only writes and lints files that actually changed
Skips generation entirely when both schema files are up to date

Test plan

 Schema generation works correctly when files need updating
 Schema generation is skipped when files are already up to date
 Linting only runs on files that were actually changed
 Build process continues to work as expected


Summary by CodeRabbit


Chores

Optimized schema generation to skip rewriting and linting when schemas are unchanged, and ensure docs/public is kept in sync.
Adds clear success messages when schemas are already up to date; failures log errors and stop the process.



Refactor

Streamlined flow for reading, comparing, and updating schema outputs with improved change detection.
Scoped linting to only changed root schema files and tightened error handling for write/copy/lint failures.

nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add schema validation job to GitHub Actions CI workflow
Ensures JSON schema files are always up-to-date

The job generates schema files and verifies no changes are needed

Prevents outdated schema files from being merged, improving documentation accuracy and release quality.
No changes to app functionality or public APIs.

nodes.message:
feat(statusline): Add visual burn rate indicators to statusline for improved accessibility (#516)

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: feat(statusline): Add visual burn rate indicators to statusline for improved accessibility
nodes.bodyText:
Problem
The statusline command uses color-only indicators to show burn rate status (green for normal, yellow for moderate, red for high).
This creates accessibility issues in environments where:

Shells don't support color output
Color output is standardized/stripped
Users have color vision deficiencies
Terminal configurations don't display colors properly

Solution
This PR adds a new --visual-burn-rate option that provides alternative visual indicators beyond color:

off (default): Color-only output (maintains backward compatibility)
emoji: Adds emoji indicators (🟢 Normal, ⚠️ Moderate, 🚨 High)
text: Adds text labels (Normal), (Moderate), (High)
emoji-text: Combines both emoji and text indicators

Changes

Added visualBurnRate argument with enum choices and short flag -vb
Refactored burn rate display logic to support multiple visual indicators
Maintains existing color coding while adding optional visual enhancements
Added proper TypeScript typing for burn status mappings

Examples
Default behavior (color only)
bun run start statusline
Add emoji indicators
bun run start statusline --visual-burn-rate emoji
Add text indicators
bun run start statusline --visual-burn-rate text
Add both emoji and text
bun run start statusline --visual-burn-rate emoji-text
Output Examples

Color only: 🔥 $2.50/hr (with color)
With emoji: 🔥 $2.50/hr 🟢
With text: 🔥 $2.50/hr (Normal)
With both: 🔥 $2.50/hr 🟢 (Normal)

This enhancement improves accessibility while maintaining full backward compatibility.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added a CLI option to control burn-rate visualization in the status line: off (default), emoji, text, or emoji-text (short flag: -vb).
Burn rate now classifies usage into Normal, Moderate, or High and displays colored indicators (green/yellow/red) with optional emoji and/or text alongside cost-per-hour.



Documentation

Added a Visual Burn Rate section with examples; content was inserted twice (duplicate copies).

nodes.message: feat: add configuration file support with JSON schema (#543)

nodes.title: feat: add configuration file support with JSON schema
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
• Add comprehensive JSON configuration file support for setting defaults and command-specific options
• Include IDE support with JSON Schema for autocomplete and validation
• Implement configuration priority system (CLI > local > user > defaults)
• Fix related code quality issues in config loader and tests
🎯 New Features

JSON Configuration Files: Set defaults and command-specific options in ccusage.json
Priority-based Configuration: CLI args override local config, which overrides user config
JSON Schema Support: IDE autocomplete and validation via config-schema.json
Multiple Locations: Local project (.ccusage/ccusage.json), user config, legacy support
Custom Config Files: Use --config to specify alternative configuration files

📍 Configuration Locations

Local project: .ccusage/ccusage.json (highest priority)
User config: ~/.config/claude/ccusage.json
Legacy location: ~/.claude/ccusage.json (lowest priority)

💡 Example Configuration
```json
{
"": "https://ccusage.com/config-schema.json",
"defaults": {
"json": false,
"mode": "auto",
"timezone": "Asia/Tokyo",
"breakdown": true
},
"commands": {
"daily": {
"instances": true
},
"blocks": {
"active": true,
"tokenLimit": "500000"
}
}
}
```
🔧 Technical Changes

Integrated `args-tokens` library for configuration management
Generated comprehensive JSON Schema with IDE support
Added extensive configuration documentation
Fixed code quality issues in config loader and tests
Updated dependencies and removed unused `zod-to-json-schema`

📚 Documentation

Complete configuration guide with examples
JSON Schema for IDE autocomplete
Team and environment-specific configuration examples
Migration guide for existing users

✅ Quality Improvements

Fixed ESLint errors: unused variables and unbound method references
Fixed TypeScript errors: missing properties and union type handling
Refactored tests: removed try-catch blocks and conditional logic
All 303 tests pass, no lint or type errors

This enables users to avoid repeating CLI options by setting project-wide or user-wide defaults, significantly improving the developer experience.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

JSON configuration support with per-command defaults, auto-discovery, and a new --config option (CLI overrides preserved).
Pre-commit now runs automatic JSON Schema generation before linting.



Documentation

Expanded Configuration guide, IDE schema guidance, and a new example config file.



Chores

JSON Schema added to the package and published/copied into docs during build.
MCP server transport switched to HTTP with updated endpoint.

refactor(statusline): implement hybrid time-based and transcript path caching (#532)

nodes.title: refactor(statusline): implement hybrid time-based and transcript path caching
nodes.bodyText:
fixes: #459
Summary

Hybrid caching strategy: Combines time-based expiry with transcript file modification detection
Time-based expiry: Cache automatically expires after refreshInterval seconds (default: 1 second)
File modification detection: Immediate cache invalidation when transcript file content changes
Configurable interval: New --refresh-interval CLI option for custom cache expiry timing

Changes
Core Implementation

Replace input hash comparison with time-based expiry using DEFAULT_REFRESH_INTERVAL_SECONDS
Add file modification time detection using Node.js fs.stat API
Update SemaphoreType structure to track lastUpdateTime and transcriptMtime
Remove unnecessary createHash import and input hash logic
Use Result pattern for file stat operations with proper error handling

CLI Enhancement

Add --refresh-interval option with default value from DEFAULT_REFRESH_INTERVAL_SECONDS
No validation limits - users can set any positive value for maximum flexibility

File Change Detection

Implement getFileModifiedTime helper function using Result pattern
Compare file mtime to detect transcript content changes
Use mtime from cache validation time to ensure data consistency
Handle file access errors gracefully with fallback to timestamp 0

Documentation

Improve JSDoc documentation explaining hybrid caching approach
Update command description to mention hybrid time+file caching
Add detailed comments for cache validation logic

Benefits

Real-time updates: Changes to transcript file content are immediately reflected
Performance: Avoids unnecessary computation when data has not changed
Accuracy: File modification detection is more reliable than path comparison
Flexibility: Users can customize cache expiry timing
Reliability: Maintains responsiveness even with frequent hook calls
Lightweight: File stat operations are much faster than content hashing

Technical Details
Cache Validation Logic
// Time-based expiry
const isExpired = timeElapsed >= refreshInterval * 1000;
// File modification detection  
const isFileModified = initialSemaphoreState.transcriptMtime !== currentMtime;
// Cache invalid if either condition is true
if (!isExpired && !isFileModified) { /* use cache */ }
Data Consistency

Uses mtime from cache validation time in semaphore to prevent race conditions
Ensures processed data matches the recorded file state
Handles concurrent file modifications correctly

Test Plan

 Existing statusline tests pass
 New --refresh-interval option works with various values
 Help text shows new option correctly
 File modification detection works correctly
 All linting and type checking passes
 Pre-commit hooks validate changes
 Scope and data consistency verified


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Status line now supports disk-backed caching with time- and file-change-based validation.
New options: enable/disable cache and set refresh interval (seconds).


Performance

Faster status line rendering via cached output and reduced recomputation.
Smarter concurrency handling to avoid redundant updates and stalls.


Refactor

Switched delay utility source with no user-visible changes.


Chores

Updated development dependencies and aliases to newer, caret-based versions.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.29.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​10283 80960b9 Thanks @​WillTaylorDev! - Support long branch names in generation of branch aliases in WCI.


#​10312 bd8223d Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Added --domain flag to wrangler deploy command for deploying to custom domains. Use --domain example.com to deploy directly to a custom domain without manually configuring routes.


#​8318 8cf47f9 Thanks @​gnekich! - Introduce json output flag for wrangler pages deployment list


Patch Changes


#​10232 e7cae16 Thanks @​emily-shen! - fix: validate wrangler containers delete ID to ensure a valid ID has been provided. Previously if you provided the container name (or any non-ID shaped string) you would get an auth error instead of a 404.


#​10139 3b6ab8a Thanks @​dom96! - Removes mention of cf-requirements when Python Workers are enabled


#​10259 c58a05c Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - Ensure that maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession considers the potential account_id from the user's wrangler config
Currently if the user has an account_id in their wrangler config file, such id won't be taken into consideration for the remote proxy session, the changes here make sure that it is (note that the auth option of maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession, if provided, takes precedence over this id value).
The changes here also fix the same issue for wrangler dev and getPlatformProxy (since they use maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession under the hook).


#​10288 42aafa3 Thanks @​tgarg-cf! - Do not attempt to update queue producer settings when deploying a Worker with a queue binding
Previously, each deployed Worker would update a subset of the queue producer's settings for each queue binding, which could result in broken queue producers or at least conflicts where different Workers tried to set different producer settings on a shared queue.


#​10242 70bd966 Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Add experimental API to expose Wrangler command tree structure for documentation generation


#​10258 d391076 Thanks @​nikitassharma! - Add the option to allow all tiers when creating a container


#​10248 422ae22 Thanks @​emily-shen! - fix: re-push container images on deploy even if the only change was to the Dockerfile


#​10179 5d5ecd5 Thanks @​pombosilva! - Prevent defining multiple workflows with the same "name" property in the same wrangler file


#​10232 e7cae16 Thanks @​emily-shen! - include containers API calls in output of WRANGLER_LOG=debug


#​10243 d481901 Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Remove async_hooks polyfill - now uses native workerd implementation
The async_hooks module is now provided natively by workerd, making the polyfill unnecessary. This improves performance and ensures better compatibility with Node.js async_hooks APIs.


#​10060 9aad334 Thanks @​edmundhung! - refactor: switch getPlatformProxy() to use Miniflare's dev registry implementation
Updated getPlatformProxy() to use Miniflare's dev registry instead of Wrangler's implementation. Previously, you had to start a wrangler or vite dev session before accessing the proxy bindings to connect to those workers. Now the order doesn't matter.


#​10219 28494f4 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix NonRetryableError thrown with an empty error message not stopping workflow retries locally

nodes.message: chore: release v15.9.7

feat(statusline): fetching context limit per model dynamically from litellm (#514)

* refactor: remove hardcoded CONTEXT_LIMIT constant

Replace fixed 200K context limit with dynamic model-specific limits

- Remove CONTEXT_LIMIT from _consts.ts as it is no longer needed

- Remove corresponding import from data-loader.ts

This prepares for implementing dynamic context limits per model

* feat: add context limit fields to model pricing schema

Add max_tokens, max_input_tokens, and max_output_tokens fields

- These fields will be used to determine model-specific context limits

- Matches LiteLLM pricing data structure

- All fields are optional to maintain backward compatibility

* feat: add getModelContextLimit method to PricingFetcher

Add method to retrieve model-specific context limits from LiteLLM data

- Returns max_input_tokens or falls back to max_tokens

- Returns null if model not found or no context limit data available

- Uses existing Result pattern for error handling

* feat: update statusline to use dynamic context limits

Pass model ID and offline flag to calculateContextTokens

- Enable model-specific context limit calculation

- Update function call to include modelId from hookData

- Pass offline flag for consistent behavior

* feat: add Claude 4 model test commands for statusline

Add npm scripts to test statusline with different Claude 4 models

- test:statusline:sonnet4 - Test with Claude 4 Sonnet

- test:statusline:opus4 - Test with Claude 4.1 Opus

- test:statusline:sonnet41 - Test with Claude 4.1 Sonnet

- test:statusline:all - Run all model tests in sequence

All tests use --offline flag for consistent testing

* test: add Claude 4 model test data for statusline

Add test fixtures for different Claude 4 model variants

- statusline-test-sonnet4.json - Claude 4 Sonnet test data

- statusline-test-opus4.json - Claude 4.1 Opus test data

- statusline-test-sonnet41.json - Claude 4.1 Sonnet test data

Each test file contains hookData with 3000 input tokens for testing context percentage calculations

* test: add unit tests for context limit functionality

Add comprehensive test coverage for dynamic context limits

- Add getModelContextLimit tests in pricing-fetcher.ts

- Add context percentage calculation tests in statusline.ts

- Test model data presence/absence scenarios

- Verify consistent percentage calculations across Claude 4 models

* docs: update lsmcp memory with dynamic context limits feature

Update symbol index status memory to reflect recent changes

- Document new getModelContextLimit method

- Record enhanced calculateContextTokens functionality

- Add testing commands for Claude 4 model variants

- Update statistics after symbol index refresh

- Mark feature as fully operational and tested

* refactor: remove inappropriate test code from statusline command

Remove test logic from statusline.ts as it should not contain tests

- Tests belong in data-loader.ts or separate test files

- Commands should focus on execution logic only

- Maintains clean separation of concerns

* style: use shortened ESLint rule names in comments

Replace @typescript-eslint/ban-ts-comment with ts/ban-ts-comment

- Use shortened ESLint rule notation for consistency

- Maintains same functionality with cleaner comments

- Follows project style guidelines

nodes.title: feat(statusline): fetching context limit per model dynamically from litellm
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR implements dynamic context limits for Claude models, replacing the hardcoded 200K limit with model-specific limits fetched from LiteLLM data.
Key Changes

Dynamic Context Calculation: Replace fixed CONTEXT_LIMIT constant with model-specific limits
LiteLLM Integration: Fetch context limits from LiteLLM pricing data (max_input_tokens or max_tokens)
Enhanced Type Safety: Add context limit fields to modelPricingSchema
Improved Statusline: Pass model ID to enable dynamic context percentage calculation
Comprehensive Testing: Add test fixtures and commands for Claude 4 model variants
Code Quality: Remove inappropriate test code from command files, maintain clean separation of concerns

Technical Implementation

PricingFetcher.getModelContextLimit() - Retrieve model-specific context limits
calculateContextTokens() - Accept modelId parameter for dynamic limit lookup
Fallback to 200K limit when model data unavailable for backward compatibility
Proper error handling and logging for context limit retrieval

Code Quality Improvements

Removed inappropriate test logic from statusline command file
Enhanced ESLint compliance with proper TypeScript private property access
Maintained separation of concerns - commands focus on execution, tests belong in appropriate modules
All quality checks pass: lint, typecheck, and build successful

Testing
New test commands added:

bun run test:statusline:sonnet4 - Test with Claude 4 Sonnet
bun run test:statusline:opus4 - Test with Claude 4.1 Opus
bun run test:statusline:sonnet41 - Test with Claude 4.1 Sonnet
bun run test:statusline:all - Run all model tests

Quality Assurance

 ESLint checks pass
 TypeScript compilation successful
 Build process completes without errors
 Unit tests for getModelContextLimit method
 Context percentage calculation tests
 Model-specific test fixtures created
 Manual testing with different Claude 4 models
 Backward compatibility verified
 Clean code architecture maintained

Backward Compatibility

Maintains 200K fallback for unknown models
No breaking changes to existing APIs
All existing functionality preserved

Implementation Details
Commits Summary (11 commits)

Remove hardcoded CONTEXT_LIMIT constant
Add context limit fields to model pricing schema
Add getModelContextLimit method to PricingFetcher
Update statusline to use dynamic context limits
Add Claude 4 model test commands
Add test data files for Claude 4 variants
Add comprehensive unit tests
Update lsmcp memory with feature documentation
Remove inappropriate test code from statusline command
Fix TypeScript private property access in tests
Use shortened ESLint rule names for consistency

This feature enables accurate, model-specific context usage reporting while maintaining excellent code quality and comprehensive test coverage.

nodes.message: chore: release v15.9.6

fix: Windows hang when CWD contains symbolic links (#497)

* fix: convert backslashes to forward slashes in glob patterns to prevent hangs on Windows

Fixes an issue where ccusage would hang indefinitely on Windows when run from
directories containing symbolic links (junction points) such as Documents,
Home directory, or C:\ root.

The issue was caused by a bug in tinyglobby where Windows absolute paths with
backslashes (e.g., C:\Users\...\**\file.jsonl) would cause the glob function
to incorrectly process the path when the current working directory contained
symbolic links, leading to an infinite hang.

By converting backslashes to forward slashes (which are cross-platform
compatible), we avoid this bug entirely while maintaining full compatibility
with all operating systems.

Tested scenarios:
- Windows paths with symlinks in CWD: now works correctly
- Windows paths without symlinks: continues to work
- Unix/Linux/macOS: unaffected (already use forward slashes)

* Improved comment

* Use path.posix.join

* Revert "Use path.posix.join"

This reverts commit 3d03ac844a777c77fd7b3bf27940f3f3b4b811b4.

* chore: format

* chore: format

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: fix: Windows hang when CWD contains symbolic links
nodes.bodyText:
Problem
ccusage would hang indefinitely on Windows when run from directories containing symbolic links (junction points) such as:

C:\Users\{username}\Documents (contains My Music, My Pictures, My Videos junctions)
C:\Users\{username} (contains My Documents, Application Data, etc.)

This issue was discovered through https://github.com/Owloops/claude-powerline which uses ccusage's loadSessionUsageById() function and would hang when run from these directories.
Root Cause
The issue is ultimately caused by a bug in tinyglobby where Windows absolute paths with backslashes (e.g., C:\Users\...\**\file.jsonl) would cause the glob function to incorrectly process the path when the current working directory contained symbolic links.
Solution
Convert backslashes to forward slashes in glob patterns. Forward slashes are cross-platform compatible and avoid the tinyglobby bug entirely.
Changes

Modified loadSessionUsageById in src/data-loader.ts to replace backslashes with forward slashes in the glob pattern

Testing
Tested the following scenarios on Windows:

✅ Running from directories WITH symlinks (Documents, Home) - now works correctly
✅ Running from directories WITHOUT symlinks - continues to work
✅ Unix/Linux/macOS compatibility - unaffected (already use forward slashes)

Technical Details
The bug manifests when:

Using Windows absolute paths with backslashes (C:\...)
Current working directory contains symbolic links/junction points
tinyglobby attempts to process the path

By converting to forward slashes, we maintain full cross-platform compatibility while avoiding the tinyglobby bug.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Fixed Windows path handling for session-usage discovery by normalizing glob patterns to use forward slashes; session usage data is now reliably found (including projects accessed via symlinked directories). No changes to commands, configuration, or outputs; behavior on macOS/Linux unchanged.

nodes.title: refactor: improve Result.pipe usage in statusline.ts
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Inline Result.unwrap() calls in all Result.pipe chains to eliminate intermediate variables
Improve contextInfo handling with cleaner display logic and N/A fallback pattern
Apply consistent functional programming pipeline pattern throughout statusline command

Changes

sessionCost: Move Result.unwrap(undefined) into pipeline, remove sessionCostResult variable
todayCost: Move Result.unwrap(0) into pipeline, remove todayCostResult variable
blockInfo/burnRateInfo: Move Result.unwrap() into pipeline, remove blockDataResult variable
contextInfo: Refactor display logic into pipeline with proper N/A fallback

Test plan

 Code builds and lints without errors
 Statusline command functionality remains unchanged
 All Result.pipe chains follow consistent pattern
 Error handling and fallback values work correctly


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Refreshed status line layout with segmented display, including context info (🧠) with “N/A” fallback, clearer session and today’s cost, and color‑coded burn rate.


Refactor

Unified error handling across data loading for more consistent behavior and logging.


Bug Fixes

Improved resilience: missing or invalid data now falls back to safe defaults, reducing misreports.


Chores

Updated a dependency to the latest patch version.

feat(statusline): add context token display to statusline command (#480)

Add context window usage tracking to the statusline hook output by:
- Reading transcript file provided by Claude Code statusline hook
- Extracting current input token count from transcript usage data
- Calculating percentage of 200K context window used
- Displaying tokens with thousand separators and color-coded percentage
  - Green: <50% (normal usage)
  - Yellow: 50-80% (moderate usage)
  - Red: >80% (high usage, approaching limit)

Format: 🧠 25,000 (13%) appears at end of statusline

Addresses user request for context window monitoring to help optimize
prompt length and prevent unexpected context management issues.

Test files included for validation of different usage levels.

nodes.title: fix: off-by-one compact date formatting
nodes.bodyText:
Suggested fix for issue #433.
formatDateCompact is being given a date in YYYY-MM-DD format that has already been converted to the local time zone. Constructing a new Date from that string interprets it as UTC, which causes an off-by-one error for users at a negative offset from UTC.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved date formatting to ensure dates in "YYYY-MM-DD" format are displayed correctly according to local time, preventing timezone-related discrepancies in the formatted output.

nodes.message:
feat(session): add --id option to session command for custom statusline integration (#477)

* feat: add --id option to session command for specific session lookup

This change exposes the loadSessionUsageById functionality through the
CLI,
allowing users to query specific session usage data programmatically.

Key improvements:
- Add --id/-i option to session command
- Support both JSON and table output formats for specific sessions
- Enable custom statusline implementations without duplicating logic
- Maintain backward compatibility with existing session listing

This addresses the limitation of the built-in statusline command by
making
the underlying session lookup functionality available for custom scripts
and integrations.

Usage:
- ccusage session --id <session-id>
- ccusage session --id <session-id> --json
- ccusage session --id <session-id> --json --jq '<query>'

* test: add comprehensive tests for --id functionality

- Test session data loading by ID using real fixtures
- Test error handling for non-existent sessions
- Validate command argument configuration
- Ensure API contract for external usage
- All tests use proper fixture-based approach without complex mocking

* fix: remove problematic test structure, rely on existing
loadSessionUsageById tests

The --id functionality directly uses loadSessionUsageById which is
already
thoroughly tested in data-loader.ts. This avoids test infrastructure
complexity
while ensuring the feature is properly covered.

* refactor: improve session command code organization and add
documentation

Implements feedback from code review:

- Extract session ID lookup logic into separate helper functions
- Improve totalTokens calculation readability with dedicated function
- Use formatDateCompact() instead of toISOString() for better date
formatting
- Add proper TypeScript types to helper functions using CostMode and
UsageData
- Add comprehensive documentation for --id option in session-reports.md

This refactoring makes the code more maintainable and follows the
single-responsibility principle while preserving all functionality.

* remove pnpm lock file

* fix: resolve TypeScript errors in session command

- Fix type safety issue with optional session ID parameter
- Update formatDateCompact to accept optional locale parameter

* Revert "fix: resolve TypeScript errors in session command"

This reverts commit 0c8c8cf22f45577cfdda6d1ef48ae622f2b64f93.

* feat(session): add --id lookup with JSON/table output; fix types

Expose loadSessionUsageById via `ccusage session --id` with jq-friendly
JSON
and table views. Align command config with sharedCommandConfig and make
formatDateCompact accept optional locale. Resolves type errors.

* refactor(session): move --id flow to helper; revert data-loader change

Keep `data-loader` untouched per guideline. Extract all session-id
lookup
logic to `src/commands/_session_id.ts`, and wire command to call it. Add
locale normalization in command layer.

* refactor(session --id): simplify output to total cost only

When --id is provided, return minimal results:
- non-JSON: print numeric total cost
- JSON: { sessionId, totalCost } (jq-friendly)
Remove helper file; keep data-loader unchanged.

* Revert "refactor(session --id): simplify output to total cost only"

This reverts commit e930f80124d2e747f6b97b0b2b6143196a085094.

* refactor(session --id): manual adjustments accepted; keep table logic

Accept manual edits: consolidate JSON/table in helper, return early from
command via direct return. All checks green.

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: fix: the documentation search is not working in production environment
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Fixed an issue where the search button in the documentation site was unresponsive in production builds.
Problem Details

Symptom: Search button in the header doesn't respond
Environment: Works correctly in docs:dev (development), but fails in bun run build + preview (https://ccusage.com/)

Root Cause Investigation
Observed Phenomena


Build-time warning messages:
[plugin vitepress] Error: This plugin assigns to bundle variable. 
This is discouraged by Rollup and is not supported by Rolldown.

This error occurred 30+ times during the build process.


rolldown-vite override configuration:
"overrides": {
  "vite": "npm:rolldown-vite@latest"
}


Environment-specific behavior:

Development: VitePress dev server works correctly (no bundling)
Production: VitePress build + preview is broken (bundling)



Analysis and Hypothesis
VitePress search functionality requires generating a search index at build time and including it in the bundle. The rolldown-vite override was causing compatibility issues with VitePress plugins when they attempted to assign to the bundle variable, which is not supported by Rolldown. This likely prevented the search functionality from being properly bundled in production builds.
Solution
Just use vite instead of rolldown-vite for now.
In the future we can fix upstream VitePress's issue to stop unrecommended procedure, that assign values to the bundle variable (described here), then re-activate rolldown-vite.
Testing Steps
bun run docs:build
bun run docs:preview
# Visit http://localhost:4173/ and verify search button works correctly
🤖 Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

No user-facing features added.


Build

Simplified docs build/dev commands by removing a custom environment variable.
Removed dependency override for Vite; builds now use default resolution.


Chores

Added .claude/settings.local.json to .gitignore to avoid committing local IDE settings.

Release Notes

honojs/hono (hono)
v4.9.0
Compare Source
Release Notes
Hono v4.9.0 is now available!
This release introduces several enhancements and utilities.
The main highlight is the new parseResponse utility that makes it easier to work with RPC client responses.
parseResponse Utility
The new parseResponse utility provides a convenient way to parse responses from Hono RPC clients (hc). It automatically handles different response formats and throws structured errors for failed requests.
import { parseResponse, DetailedError } from 'hono/client'

// result contains the parsed response body (automatically parsed based on Content-Type)
const result = await parseResponse(client.hello.$get()).catch(
  // parseResponse automatically throws an error if response is not ok
  (e: DetailedError) => {
    console.error(e)
  }
)
This makes working with RPC client responses much more straightforward and type-safe.
Thanks @​NamesMT!
New features

nodes.message:
ci: split lint/check and test into separate jobs

Separate jobs allow for better parallelization and clearer CI status

- lint-check job: runs eslint and typecheck

- test job: runs tests with coverage and includes jq check for test requirements

ci: simplify jq setup by checking availability only

GitHub Actions environments already have jq pre-installed, so we only need to verify it exists rather than installing it

This removes unnecessary apt-get update/install steps, making CI runs faster

fix!: add offline mode support to statusline command (#471)

* fix\!: add offline mode support to statusline command

BREAKING CHANGE: statusline command now accepts CLI arguments

- Add --offline flag to statusline command for cached pricing data usage

- Pass offline flag to all data loading functions (loadSessionUsageById, loadDailyUsageData, loadSessionBlockData)

- Update documentation with offline mode configuration examples

- Enables faster performance without network dependencies to LiteLLM API

This is a breaking change as the statusline command signature has changed from accepting no arguments to accepting the --offline flag. However, existing configurations will continue to work without modification.

* fix\!: make offline mode default for statusline command

BREAKING CHANGE: statusline now defaults to offline mode for better performance

- Set offline mode as default (true) for statusline command

- Update documentation to reflect offline as default behavior

- Users can opt-in to online mode with --no-offline flag

- Provides instant response times without network latency

This change prioritizes performance for the statusline which needs to be responsive. The cached pricing data is sufficient for most use cases and eliminates network dependencies.

* simplified test statusline

nodes.title: fix!: add offline mode support to statusline command
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds offline mode support to the statusline command and makes it the default for optimal performance. The statusline now uses cached pricing data by default, eliminating network latency.
Breaking Change
⚠️ BREAKING:

The statusline command now accepts CLI arguments (specifically --offline/--no-offline)
Offline mode is now the default behavior (previously required network access)

While this changes the command signature and default behavior, existing configurations will continue to work without modification.
Changes

✨ Add --offline flag to statusline command arguments
🚀 Set offline mode as default for instant response times
🔧 Pass offline flag to all data loading functions:

loadSessionUsageById()
loadDailyUsageData()
loadSessionBlockData()


📚 Update documentation to reflect offline as default behavior
🌐 Add --no-offline flag for users who need latest pricing from API

Benefits

Instant Response: No network latency - critical for status line updates
Offline Support: Works without internet connection
Better UX: Status line updates immediately without waiting for API calls
Reduced API Load: Fewer requests to external pricing service
Consistent Pricing: Uses stable, cached pricing data

Usage
Default Mode (Offline - Recommended)
{
  "statusLine": {
    "type": "command",
    "command": "bun x ccusage statusline"  // Uses cached pricing (fast)
  }
}
Online Mode (Optional)
{
  "statusLine": {
    "type": "command",
    "command": "bun x ccusage statusline --no-offline"  // Fetches from API (slower)
  }
}
Testing

✅ All tests pass
✅ Tested with sample statusline hook JSON
✅ Verified backward compatibility (existing configs work)
✅ Confirmed offline mode is now default
✅ Verified --no-offline flag enables online mode

Migration
No migration required. Existing configurations will continue to work but will now use offline mode by default for better performance. Users who need the latest pricing data can explicitly add --no-offline to their command.

nodes.title: feat: add --jq option for direct JSON processing
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds a new  option to all ccusage commands, allowing users to process JSON output directly with jq filters without using pipes.
Changes

✨ Add  option to all commands (daily, monthly, weekly, session, blocks)
🔧 Implement  utility using nano-spawn and @praha/byethrow Result pattern
📝 Update documentation with examples of the new --jq option
✅ Add comprehensive tests for jq processing functionality
🔧 Update GitHub Actions CI to install jq for testing

Usage Examples
Instead of using pipes:
# Old way
ccusage daily --json | jq '.totals.totalCost'

# New way
ccusage daily --jq '.totals.totalCost'
More examples:
# Get the most expensive session
ccusage session --jq '.sessions | sort_by(.totalCost) | reverse | .[0]'

# Get daily costs as CSV
ccusage daily --jq '.daily[] | [.date, .totalCost] | @csv'

# Calculate average daily cost
ccusage daily --jq '[.daily[].totalCost] | add / length'
Important Notes

The --jq option implies --json (users don't need to specify both)
Requires jq to be installed on the system
Returns helpful error messages if jq is not installed or if the jq syntax is invalid

Test Plan

 Tested all commands with --jq option locally
 Added unit tests for processWithJq function
 CI updated to install jq and run tests
 Documentation updated with examples


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added a new --jq command-line option to enable direct JSON output processing using jq filters within the tool.
JSON output can now be filtered and transformed inline using jq expressions, without needing to pipe to an external jq command.
If jq is not installed, users receive a clear error message with installation guidance.



Documentation

Added detailed instructions and examples for using the new --jq option in the user guide.
Clarified the distinction between built-in jq processing and traditional jq usage via pipes.



Chores

Updated continuous integration workflow to ensure jq is available in the test environment.
Added a development dependency for process spawning utilities.

^4.28.0 -> ^4.28.1








WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.28.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#​10130 773cca3 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - update maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession config argument (to allow callers to specify an environment)
Before this change maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession could be called with either the path to a wrangler config file or the configuration of a worker. The former override however did not allow the caller to specify an environment, so the maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession API has been updated so that in the wrangler config case an object (with the path and a potential environment) needs to be passed instead.
For example, before callers could invoke the function in the following way
await maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession(configPath);
note that there is no way to tell the function what environment to use when parsing the wrangle configuration.
Now callers will instead call the function in the following way:
await maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession({
	path: configPath,
	environment: targetEnvironment,
});
note that now a target environment can be specified.


#​10130 773cca3 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix getPlatformProxy not taking into account the potentially specified environment for remote bindings


#​10122 2e8eb24 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix startWorker not respecting auth options for remote bindings
fix startWorker currently not taking into account the auth field
that can be provided as part of the dev options when used in conjunction
with remote bindings
example:
Given the following
import { unstable_startWorker } from "wrangler";

const worker = await unstable_startWorker({
	entrypoint: "./worker.js",
	bindings: {
		AI: {
			type: "ai",
			experimental_remote: true,
		},
	},
	dev: {
		experimentalRemoteBindings: true,
		auth: {
			accountId: "<ACCOUNT_ID>",
			apiToken: {
				apiToken: "<API_TOKEN>",
			},
		},
	},
});

await worker.ready;
wrangler will now use the provided <ACCOUNT_ID> and <API_TOKEN> to integrate with
the remote AI binding instead of requiring the user to authenticate.


#​10209 93c4c26 Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - fix: strip ANSI escape codes from log files to improve readability and parsing


#​9774 48853a6 Thanks @​nikitassharma! - Validate container configuration against account limits in wrangler to give early feedback to the user


#​10122 2e8eb24 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix incorrect TypeScript type for AI binding in the startWorker API

chore: release v15.9.1

fix(statusline): use correct date format for daily usage filtering

The statusline command was passing dates in YYYY-MM-DD format to loadDailyUsageData,

but filterByDateRange expects YYYYMMDD format for since/until parameters.

This caused today's usage to be incorrectly filtered out, showing 0 cost.
chore: release v15.9.0

fix(statusline): correctly load session costs using actual session IDs (#452)

* feat: add sessionId and cwd in usage file

* fix(statusline): correctly load session costs using actual session IDs

Previously, statusline was trying to extract session IDs from transcript paths, but should use the session_id field directly from hook data.

Changes:

- Add loadSessionUsageById() function to find and load specific session JSONL files

- Update statusline command to use session_id from hook data to find the correct JSONL file

- Remove path parsing logic and use direct session ID lookup

- Add comprehensive tests with vitest environment mocking and afterEach cleanup

- Update CLAUDE.md to clarify the naming confusion between project directories and actual sessions

nodes.title: fix(statusline): correctly load session costs using actual session IDs
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Fixed session cost calculation in statusline command to use actual session IDs from hook data
Added new loadSessionUsageById() function to properly locate and load specific session JSONL files
Improved test coverage with vitest environment mocking

Problem
The statusline command was incorrectly trying to extract session IDs from transcript paths instead of using the session_id field directly from hook data. This caused session costs to not be displayed correctly.
Solution

Created dedicated function loadSessionUsageById() that searches for JSONL files by their actual session ID (filename)
Updated statusline command to use the session_id from hook data directly

nodes.message:
feat: add statusline command for Claude Code status bar integration (#450)

* feat: add statusline type

* feat: add statusline command for Claude Code status bar integration

Adds a new statusline command that displays compact usage information designed for Claude Code status line feature.

Features:

- Shows current session cost, today total, and active block status

- Color-coded burn rate indicator (green/yellow/red) using picocolors

- Reads session data from stdin as per Claude Code hook protocol

- Compact single-line output optimized for status bar display

- Test scripts and dummy test file included for easy testing

Output format: 🤖 Model | 💰 $X.XX session / $X.XX today / $X.XX block (Xh Xm left) | 🔥 $X.XX/hr

This is a Beta feature with more customization options planned.

* fix: update statusline schema to match actual Claude Code data format

Removed hook_event_name field which is not present in actual data

Added optional version field

Updated test file to match real data structure

Replaced logger with console.log for cleaner output

Removed error displays for silent failures

* agg get-stdin

* add bunx npx

nodes.title: feat: add statusline command for Claude Code status bar integration
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Adds new  command for Claude Code status bar integration
Shows real-time usage metrics in a compact single-line format
Beta feature with color-coded burn rate indicators

Features
Core Functionality

Session Cost Tracking: Displays current conversation session cost
Daily Total: Shows cumulative spending for the current day
Block Status: Tracks active 5-hour billing block with remaining time
Burn Rate: Color-coded cost per hour indicator (green/yellow/red)
Model Display: Shows active Claude model at the beginning

Technical Implementation

Reads session data from stdin as JSON (Claude Code hook protocol)
Uses picocolors for color-coded burn rate indicators
Compact output format optimized for status bar display
Includes test scripts and dummy test file for easy testing

Output Format
Test Plan

 Test with dummy JSON input via 🤖 Opus | 💰 $0.00 session / $0.00 today / $30.57 block (3h 43m left) | 🔥 $37.50/hr
 Verify color-coded burn rate indicators work correctly
 Confirm session cost calculation from session ID
 Test with no active block scenario
 Run format and typecheck
 Test with actual Claude Code integration

Documentation

Added comprehensive documentation in
Updated README with new command
Added test scripts to package.json

Notes
This is a Beta feature. Future enhancements planned:

Custom format templates
Configurable burn rate thresholds
Additional metrics display options


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Introduced a new "Statusline Integration" (Beta) for displaying a compact, real-time status line with Claude Code usage statistics.
Added a CLI command to show the status line and updated documentation with setup and usage instructions.


Documentation

Added a detailed guide for the new status line feature, including setup, output examples, and troubleshooting.
Updated usage examples and feature list in the README to reflect the new status line integration.


Tests

Added a test fixture for simulating status line input and new test scripts for the status line feature.

Compare Source
Minor Changes

#​9530 e82aa19 Thanks @​Akshit222! - Add --json flag to r2 bucket info command for machine-readable output.

Patch Changes


#​10004 b4d1373 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix wrangler dev logs being logged on the incorrect level in some cases
currently the way wrangler dev prints logs is faulty, for example the following code
console.error("this is an error");
console.warn("this is a warning");
console.debug("this is a debug");
inside a worker would cause the following logs:
✘ [ERROR] this is an error

✘ [ERROR] this is a warning

this is a debug

(note that the warning is printed as an error and the debug log is printed even if by default it should not)
the changes here make sure that the logs are instead logged to their correct level, so for the code about the following will be logged instead:
✘ [ERROR] this is an error

▲ [WARNING] this is a warning

(running wrangler dev with the --log-level=debug flag will also cause the debug log to be included as well)


#​10099 360004d Thanks @​emily-shen! - fix: move local dev container cleanup to process exit hook. This should ensure containers are cleaned up even when Wrangler is shut down programatically.


#​10186 dae1377 Thanks @​matthewdavidrodgers! - Deleting when Pages project binds to worker requires confirmation


#​10169 1655bec Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - fix: report startup errors before workerd profiling


#​10136 354a001 Thanks @​nikitassharma! - Update wrangler containers images list to make fewer API calls to improve command runtime


#​10157 5c3b83f Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Enforce 64-character limit for Workflow binding names locally to match production validation


#​10154 502a8e0 Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Fix UTF BOM handling in config files - remove UTF-8 BOM and error on other BOMs


#​10176 07c8611 Thanks @​devin-ai-integration! - Add macOS version validation to prevent EPIPE errors on unsupported macOS versions (below 13.5). Miniflare and C3 fail hard while Wrangler shows warnings but continues execution.

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.27.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​9914 a24c9d8 Thanks @​petebacondarwin! - Add support for loading local dev vars from .env files
If there are no .dev.vars or .dev.vars.<environment> files, when running Wrangler or the Vite plugin in local development mode,
they will now try to load additional local dev vars from .env, .env.local, .env.<environment> and .env.<environment>.local files.
These loaded vars are only for local development and have no effect in production to the vars in a deployed Worker.
Wrangler and Vite will continue to load .env files in order to configure themselves as a tool.
Further details:

In vite build the local vars will be computed and stored in a .dev.vars file next to the compiled Worker code, so that vite preview can use them.
The wrangler types command will similarly read the .env files (if no .dev.vars files) in order to generate the Env interface.
If the CLOUDFLARE_LOAD_DEV_VARS_FROM_DOT_ENV environment variable is "false" then local dev variables will not be loaded from .env files.
If the CLOUDFLARE_INCLUDE_PROCESS_ENV environment variable is "true" then all the environment variables found on process.env will be included as local dev vars.
Wrangler (but not Vite plugin) also now supports the --env-file=<path/to/dotenv/file> global CLI option. This affects both loading .env to configure Wrangler the tool as well as loading local dev vars.



Patch Changes


#​10051 0f7820e Thanks @​nikitassharma! - Add support for custom instance limits for containers. For example, instead of
having to use the preconfigured dev/standard/basic instance types, you can now
set:
instance_type: {
  vcpu: 1,
  memory_mib: 1024,
  disk_mb: 4000
}

This feature is currently only available to customers on an enterprise plan.


#​10149 e9bb8d3 Thanks @​vicb! - fix require("debug") in nodejs_compat mode
