nodes.title: feat: add locale option for date/time formatting
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add `--locale` option to all ccusage commands for customizable date/time formatting
Default to `en-CA` locale for ISO date format (YYYY-MM-DD) and 24-hour time
Support automatic 12/24 hour time switching based on locale (e.g., en-US uses 12-hour, ja-JP uses 24-hour)

Changes

✨ Add `--locale`/`-l` option to shared command arguments with default value `en-CA`
📝 Update `formatDate` and `formatDateCompact` functions to accept locale parameter
🔧 Pass locale option through all data loading functions
🌐 Update blocks command to use locale for time display (`toLocaleString`)
🧪 Add comprehensive tests for locale functionality
📚 Update README and configuration documentation with locale examples
🔌 Update MCP server to accept locale parameter

Examples
```bash
Use US English locale (12-hour time format)
ccusage daily --locale en-US
Use Japanese locale (24-hour time format)
ccusage blocks --locale ja-JP
Use German locale (24-hour time format)
ccusage session -l de-DE
Default behavior (uses en-CA for ISO format)
ccusage daily
```
Test plan

 Run `bun run format` - All files formatted correctly
 Run `bun typecheck` - No type errors
 Run `bun run test` - All 257 tests pass
 Test with different locales manually
 Review documentation changes
 Test MCP server with locale parameter


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for a --locale option to customize date and time formatting in reports and outputs, allowing users to specify regional formats (e.g., en-US, ja-JP, de-DE).



Documentation

Updated user guides and README to explain the new --locale option, with examples and use cases for internationalization and regional preferences.

nodes.title: feat: add timezone option for date grouping
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Added --timezone/-z option to all commands for configurable date grouping
Users can now specify any valid IANA timezone (e.g., UTC, America/New_York, Asia/Tokyo)
Default behavior remains unchanged - uses system timezone when not specified

Why this change?
Following up on #414, this PR adds proper timezone support as a command-line option rather than relying on environment variables. This provides a more flexible and user-friendly way to control date grouping across different timezones.
Changes

Added timezone option to shared command arguments
Updated formatDate and formatDateCompact functions to accept timezone parameter
Modified all commands (daily, monthly, weekly, session, blocks) to pass timezone option
Updated MCP server to accept timezone parameter
Added comprehensive tests for timezone functionality
Updated documentation with timezone usage examples

Examples
# Use UTC timezone for consistent reports
ccusage daily --timezone UTC

# Use specific timezone
ccusage daily --timezone America/New_York
ccusage monthly -z Asia/Tokyo

# Default behavior (system timezone)
ccusage daily
Test plan

 All existing tests pass
 Added new tests for timezone parameter functionality
 Manual testing with different timezones
 Documentation updated


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for specifying a timezone in daily, weekly, monthly, session, and blocks usage reports via a new --timezone (-z) command-line option.
Date grouping and formatting in reports now respect the selected timezone, allowing for consistent reporting across different regions and use cases.



Documentation

Updated user guides and README with instructions, examples, and use cases for the new timezone support feature.
Clarified configuration environment variable documentation.

nodes.message: chore: release v15.6.1

fix: use local timezone for date grouping instead of UTC (#414)

The date formatters were using UTC timezone which caused usage data to be
grouped incorrectly. For example, usage at 20:00 local time would appear
on the next day if the local timezone was behind UTC.

This regression was introduced in PR #409 (commit f7c5251) which added
explicit UTC timezone to the Intl.DateTimeFormat configuration.

The fix removes the hardcoded 'timeZone: UTC' option, allowing the
formatters to respect the system's local timezone or the TZ environment
variable if set.

Changes:
- Remove 'timeZone: UTC' from dateFormatter
- Remove 'timeZone: UTC' from datePartsFormatter
- Update comment to reflect local timezone usage

This ensures usage data is grouped by the user's local date boundaries
rather than UTC date boundaries.

nodes.title: fix: use local timezone for date grouping instead of UTC
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR fixes an issue where usage data was being grouped by UTC date boundaries instead of the user's local timezone, causing data to appear on incorrect dates.
Fixes #413
Caused by #409
Problem
When using ccusage, usage data was being grouped incorrectly based on UTC time rather than the user's local timezone. This caused confusing results where:

Usage at 20:00 local time (MDT) would appear on the next day's report
Daily summaries didn't align with when users actually used Claude Code
Users in timezones behind UTC would see their evening usage shifted to the following day

Example
A user in MDT (UTC-6) using Claude Code at 8:00 PM on August 3rd would see that usage reported as August 4th, because 8:00 PM MDT is 2:00 AM UTC the next day.
Solution
Removed the hardcoded timeZone: 'UTC' configuration from the Intl.DateTimeFormat instances in data-loader.ts. This allows the date formatters to:

Use the system's local timezone by default
Respect the TZ environment variable if users want to override it
Group usage data by local date boundaries as users would expect

Changes

Removed timeZone: 'UTC' from dateFormatter
Removed timeZone: 'UTC' from datePartsFormatter
Updated comment to reflect local timezone usage

Testing

All 253 existing tests pass
Verified that usage data now groups correctly by local date
Confirmed that the TZ environment variable can still override timezone if needed
Linting and type checking pass without issues

Backward Compatibility
This change makes the date grouping more intuitive and correct for users. The data itself is unchanged - only the grouping/display is affected. Users who need UTC grouping can still achieve it by setting TZ=UTC.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Dates are now displayed and grouped according to your local timezone instead of UTC, providing a more intuitive experience for users in different regions.

nodes.message: chore: release v15.6.0

refactor: use Intl.DateTimeFormat for date formatting (#409)

Replace manual date string construction with Intl.DateTimeFormat API

Benefits:

- More robust timezone handling (using UTC explicitly)

- Standards-compliant implementation

- Better performance with native browser/Node.js APIs

- Future-proof for internationalization needs

Implementation details:

- Use en-CA locale for YYYY-MM-DD format in formatDate()

- Use formatToParts() for flexible formatting in formatDateCompact()

- Maintain backward compatibility with existing date formats

nodes.title: refactor: use Intl.DateTimeFormat for date formatting
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors date formatting functions to use the standard Intl.DateTimeFormat API instead of manual string construction.
Changes

Replace manual date parsing with Intl.DateTimeFormat in formatDate() function
Use formatToParts() for flexible formatting in formatDateCompact() function
Explicitly use UTC timezone to avoid timezone-related issues

Benefits

More robust timezone handling: Explicitly using UTC prevents timezone-related bugs
Standards-compliant: Uses native browser/Node.js APIs instead of manual string manipulation
Better performance: Native implementation is typically faster than JavaScript string operations
Future-proof: Ready for internationalization if needed in the future

Technical Details

en-CA locale is used for YYYY-MM-DD format (Canadian English uses ISO 8601 date format)
formatToParts() allows extracting individual date components for custom formatting
All existing tests pass without modification, confirming backward compatibility

Testing

✅ All existing tests pass
✅ Date formatting output remains unchanged
✅ No breaking changes to public API

nodes.message:
feat: use only CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR paths when environment variable is set (#365)

When CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is set, the tool now exclusively uses those paths
instead of aggregating with default paths. This gives users explicit control
over which Claude data directories are included in usage reports.

- Modified getClaudePaths() to return early when env paths are found
- Updated JSDoc to reflect the new behavior
- Preserves backward compatibility when CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is not set

nodes.title: feat!: exclusive CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR mode for isolated directory usage
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR introduces an exclusive mode for CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR that allows users to isolate their usage reports to specific directories only, rather than aggregating across all available Claude installations.
Closes #360
Motivation
Currently, when CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is set, ccusage aggregates data from both the specified directory AND the default directories (~/.config/claude and ~/.claude). This can be confusing when users want to analyze usage from a specific Claude installation in isolation.
This change makes the behavior more intuitive:

When CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is set: Use ONLY those specified paths
When CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is not set: Use default paths as before

Changes

Modified getClaudePaths() in src/data-loader.ts to return early when environment paths are found
Updated JSDoc to reflect the new exclusive behavior
Added development workflow documentation with justfile for easy maintenance
Documented shell function patterns for convenient directory switching

Usage Examples
Users can now create shell aliases for different Claude installations:
# Function for default directories only
ccuse() {
    CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="" ccusage "$@"
}

# Function for specific installation
ccuse-work() {
    CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="$HOME/.claude-work" ccusage "$@"
}

# Usage
ccuse daily          # Shows only default directories
ccuse-work daily     # Shows only work directory
Breaking Changes
None. This change maintains backward compatibility:

Users not setting CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR see no change
Users setting CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR get more predictable, isolated results

Testing
Tested locally with multiple Claude installations:

Verified exclusive mode shows only specified directory data
Confirmed default behavior unchanged when env var not set
Validated --instances and --project filters work correctly

Development Workflow
Added a justfile for contributors who want to maintain local modifications:

just update - Full workflow to sync with upstream
just rebuild - Quick rebuild after changes
Supports easy rebasing of local changes on upstream updates

Screenshots
Before (aggregated):
CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path ccusage daily
# Shows data from: /custom/path + ~/.config/claude + ~/.claude

After (exclusive):
CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path ccusage daily  
# Shows data from: /custom/path ONLY


Summary by CodeRabbit


Bug Fixes

Improved handling of configuration directory selection by prioritizing environment variable paths exclusively and providing clearer error messages when invalid paths are specified.



Chores

Updated logic for determining valid configuration directories for a more predictable and user-friendly experience.

 Run bun run test to verify tests still work correctly
 Confirm that tests do not automatically re-run when files change

nodes.message:
Add weekly usage command (#378)

* Add repo level VSCode configuration to gitignore

* Add command for getting weekly usage

* Fix bug in week sorting.

* Add tests for loadWeeklyUsageData

* Fix misleading comments

* Refactor to consolidate aggregated data reporting

* Start weekly window on the date of the rollout

* no .vscode

* chore: remove luxon

* feat: add configurable start of week parameter to weekly command

- Add --start-of-week/-w flag to weekly command with default of Thursday

- Update getDateWeek function to accept configurable start day parameter

- Add type-fest dependency for better TypeScript utility types

- Use ValueOf and satisfies for improved type safety

- Remove Luxon dependency to reduce bundle size by ~50KB

* refactor: improve weekly command implementation

- Change default start of week from Thursday to Sunday

- Extract getDayNumber function for better code organization

- Move dayNameToNumber mapping to module level as const

- Use getDayNumber("sunday") instead of magic number 0

* refactor: add DayOfWeek type using IntRange for type safety

- Define DayOfWeek type as IntRange<0, 7> for day number validation

- Update getDayNumber return type to use DayOfWeek

- Update getDateWeek parameter type to use DayOfWeek

- Improve type safety by restricting day numbers to valid range

* refactor: centralize WEEK_DAYS constant definition

- Move WEEK_DAYS to _consts.ts to avoid duplication

- Update imports in weekly.ts and data-loader.ts

- Use typeof WEEK_DAYS[number] for WeekDay type definition

* refactor: derive DayOfWeek type from WEEK_DAYS length

- Use typeof WEEK_DAYS["length"] instead of hardcoded 7

- Automatically adjust type range if days are added/removed

- Improve maintainability and reduce magic numbers

* refactor: use TupleToUnion from type-fest for WeekDay type

- Replace typeof WEEK_DAYS[number] with TupleToUnion<typeof WEEK_DAYS>

- Leverage type-fest utility for more explicit type transformation

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: Add weekly usage command
nodes.bodyText:
This adds a weekly usage command. (#375) From what I read, it wasn't exactly clear how they were going to set the usage window so I added code that makes it work for both Sunday and Monday. When we know how the windows are going to work we can update it. I tested both though and they both seem to work.
With it set to Monday:

With it set to Sunday:

For now I left it set to Monday because I think that'll most likely be the day they reset it since it's the first day of the working week.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added weekly usage reporting, allowing users to view aggregated token usage and costs by week.
Introduced a new CLI command to generate weekly usage reports with options for JSON or table output, filtering, and detailed breakdowns.
Enhanced data aggregation to support grouping usage by arbitrary time buckets (weekly or monthly).
Added support for weekly usage data type across calculations and validations.
Introduced configurable start day of the week for weekly reports.



Bug Fixes

Ensured tests run consistently in the UTC timezone.



Chores

Updated development dependencies to earlier versions for improved compatibility.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.26.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#​10061 f8a80a8 Thanks @​emily-shen! - feat(containers): try to automatically get the socket path that the container engine is listening on.
Currently, if your container engine isn't set up to listen on unix:///var/run/docker.sock (or isn't symlinked to that), then you have to manually set this via the dev.containerEngine field in your Wrangler config, or via the env vars WRANGLER_DOCKER_HOST. This change means that we will try and get the socket of the current context automatically. This should reduce the occurrence of opaque internal errors thrown by the runtime when the daemon is not listening on unix:///var/run/docker.sock.
In addition to WRANGLER_DOCKER_HOST, DOCKER_HOST can now also be used to set the container engine socket address.


#​10048 dbdbb8c Thanks @​vicb! - pass the compatibility date and flags to the unenv preset


#​10096 687655f Thanks @​vicb! - bump unenv to 2.0.0-rc.19


#​9897 755a249 Thanks @​edmundhung! - fix: wrangler types should infer the types of the default worker entrypoint

nodes.bodyText:

Package
Change
Age
Adoption
Passing
Confidence




wrangler (source)
^4.25.1 -> ^4.26.0








WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.26.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​10016 c5b291d Thanks @​emily-shen! - Interactively handle wrangler deploys that are probably assets-only, where there is no config file and flags are incorrect or missing.
For example:
npx wrangler deploy ./public will now ask if you meant to deploy a folder of assets only, ask for a name, set the compat date and then ask whether to write your choices out to wrangler.json for subsequent deployments.
npx wrangler deploy --assets=./public will now ask for a name, set the compat date and then ask whether to write your choices out to wrangler.json for subsequent deployments.
In non-interactive contexts, Wrangler will error as it currently does.


#​9971 19794bf Thanks @​edmundhung! - Improved script source display on the pretty error screen


Patch Changes


#​9800 3d4f946 Thanks @​helloimalastair! - remove banner from r2 getobject in pipe mode


#​9910 7245101 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - make sure that the ready-on message is printed after the appropriate runtime controller is ready
fix the fact that when starting a local (or remote) dev session the log saying Ready on http://localhost:xxxx could be displayed before the runtime is actually ready to handle requests (this is quite noticeable when locally running dev sessions with containers, where the ready message currently gets displayed before the container images building/pulling process)


#​10031 823cba8 Thanks @​vicb! - wrangler and vite-plugin now depend upon the latest version of unenv-preset


#​10032 154acf7 Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - add support for containers in wrangler multiworker dev
currently when running wrangler dev with different workers (meaning that the -c|--config flag is used multiple times) containers are not being included, meaning that trying to interact with them at runtime would not work and cause errors instead. The changes here address the above making wrangler correctly detect and wire up the containers.


#​9988 7fb0bfd Thanks @​penalosa! - Correctly label mtls remote bindings warning


Updated dependencies [823cba8, 19794bf, 059a39e]:

@​cloudflare/unenv-preset@​2.4.1
miniflare@4.20250712.2

nodes.message:
fix(live-monitor): Fix layout collapse in narrow terminal width (#328)

* fix(live-monitor): Fix the problem that progress bar columns overflowing their borders

* fix(live-monitor): Fix the problem that Usage, Projection details are overflowing their borders

* fix(live-monitor): Omit elapsed time in SESSION section to prevent overflowing borders

* fix(live-monitor): Remove minimum width clamp on progress bar

* refactor(live-monitor): extract common layout constants for detail sections

* feat(live-monitor): Re-render when resized

* fix(live-monitor): Fix exceeding limits of resize event listeners count

* fix(live-monitor): Fix the problem that last event listener of resize isn not removed

* refactor(live-monitor): Calculate t`otalWidth` linearly

Co-authored-by: gemini-code-assist[bot] <176961590+gemini-code-assist[bot]@users.noreply.github.com>

* use !=null instead of undefined

---------

Co-authored-by: gemini-code-assist[bot] <176961590+gemini-code-assist[bot]@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: fix(live-monitor): Fix layout collapse in narrow terminal width
nodes.bodyText:
The branch name is fix-issue-172, but this does not fix issue #172.
(It is a confusing branch name because I tried to create a PR out first that fixes another issue found while working on this issue. Sorry!)
Changes


In live monitor, to avoid breaking borders when the terminal is narrow, do the following:

The progress bar is shortened.
Margins are reduced.
Token counts, etc. are shortened using k.
More information is displayed on two lines.



In live monitor, re-render the terminal when it is resized.


Screenshots


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

The display now adapts dynamically to available space, adjusting column layouts and formatting for improved readability.
Token counts and usage details automatically switch between full and short formats based on space constraints.
Session, usage, and projection sections intelligently reformat to fit content, using multi-line layouts when needed.



Improvements

Progress bars and text elements resize dynamically for better alignment and presentation.
The interface updates immediately upon terminal resize for a more responsive experience.

nodes.message: chore: release v15.5.0

feat: add project filtering and grouping to daily command (#183)

* feat: add multi-instance support with project grouping

- Add --instances flag to show usage grouped by project
- Add --project filter to show specific project data
- Add custom project name aliases via CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES env var
- Implement improved project name parsing and formatting
- Support both table and JSON output formats across all commands
- Maintain full backward compatibility

🤖 Generated with Claude Code

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* fix: resolve critical merge blockers for multi-instance support

- Fix TypeScript compilation errors in grouping functions
- Add Windows path compatibility to project extraction
- Correct JSDoc documentation for project name parsing

All blockers now resolved for --instances feature.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* test: add comprehensive integration tests for multi-instance feature

- Add 19 integration tests across all commands (daily, monthly, session, blocks)
- Test --instances flag functionality with project grouping
- Test --project filtering with edge cases
- Test JSON output structure consistency
- Test Windows path compatibility in blocks command
- Test extractProjectFromBlock function with fallback logic

Eliminates critical test coverage gap for user-facing multi-instance functionality.
Previously had ZERO command-level integration tests for --instances/--project flags.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* test: add project name formatting integration tests for daily command

Add comprehensive tests validating formatProjectName integration in --instances mode:
- Test complex project name formatting in table headers
- Test project alias resolution in grouped output
- Verify proper integration between formatProjectName and table rendering logic
- Fix TypeScript type assertion issues in existing tests

This completes the "Test project name formatting in output" task from TODO.md Phase 3.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* feat: improve type safety for groupByProject functions

- Add TypeScript interfaces for JSON output structures
- Replace Record<string, any[]> with proper typed interfaces
- Add comprehensive type validation tests for all commands
- Address Gemini Code Assist review comments (PR #183)

Includes:
- DailyProjectOutput, MonthlyProjectOutput, SessionProjectOutput, BlockProjectOutput interfaces
- Type validation tests ensuring JSON output conforms to interfaces
- Updated function signatures across all command files

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* chore: remove TODO.md from git tracking

The TODO.md file was accidentally committed despite being in .gitignore.
Remove it from tracking while keeping it in .gitignore for local development use.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* feat: scope --instances flag to daily command only

- Remove --instances and --project flags from monthly, session, blocks commands
- Move instances/project args from shared to daily-specific configuration
- Remove project grouping logic from non-daily commands
- Simplify JSON output types to daily-only scope
- Addresses user feedback about --instances providing "nothing useful" for blocks command

BREAKING CHANGE: --instances flag removed from monthly, session, and blocks commands

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* style: clean import formatting in blocks.ts

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* fix: address all PR review feedback from CodeRabbit and maintainer

• Fix project name parsing logic with explicit UUID pattern handling
• Resolve TypeScript type safety issues throughout codebase
• Replace unsafe '|' separator with null character in grouping keys
• Add comprehensive PROJECT_ALIASES_ENV justification and documentation
• Remove duplicate .eslintcache entry from .gitignore
• Fix vitest import patterns to avoid top-level await
• Improve test reliability and type assertions

All critical feedback addressed, quality checks passing.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* chore: revert .eslintcache

* docs: add comprehensive documentation for multiple-instance feature

- Update README.md with --instances and --project flag examples
- Add multi-instance support to features list
- Document CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable in configuration guide
- Explain intelligent project name formatting system
- Add --instances flag behavior documentation to daily reports guide
- Document --project filtering capability with visual examples
- Add practical use cases for project analysis and team usage
- Document new {projects: {...}} JSON structure in JSON output guide
- Contrast standard vs project-grouped JSON output formats
- Update integration examples with project-based analysis (jq, Python, Node.js)

Closes documentation gap for the multiple-instance feature implementation.
Users can now discover and effectively use project grouping and filtering capabilities.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* refactor: clean up test imports and remove unnecessary code

- Remove unnecessary vitest destructuring imports

- Replace top-level await imports with regular imports

- Clean up dynamic imports that were already imported at module level

- Move fs-fixture and test utility imports to top of files

* refactor: address maintainer's critical feedback

- Move grouping logic from commands/daily.ts to new _daily-grouping.ts module
- Remove all test blocks from command files (830+ lines removed)
- Add minimal focused tests to _daily-grouping.ts (~90 lines)
- Fix all timezone-related test failures by using noon UTC timestamps
- Fix integration test timeout by increasing limit to 30s
- Reduce daily.ts from 1124 to 243 lines

This addresses the maintainer's three main concerns:
1. No logic in command files
2. No tests in command files
3. Excessive test length reduced

* refactor: remove unnecessary type annotations

- Remove explicit string type annotation from USER_HOME_DIR and XDG_CONFIG_DIR in _consts.ts

- Remove explicit number type annotation from costUSD in _live-monitor.ts

This change was unrelated to the PR main purpose of adding project filtering

Remove @praha/byethrow Result.try usage and restore original try-catch patterns

Restore Result.unwrap usage in calculateCostForEntry to match main branch

These changes were unrelated to the PR main purpose of adding project filtering

nodes.title: feat: add project filtering and grouping to daily command
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Adds project filtering and grouping support to the daily command for tracking Claude Code usage across multiple parallel sessions.
• Project grouping: New --instances flag displays daily usage breakdown by project
• Project filtering: New --project flag filters daily results to specific projects
• Smart aliases: Configure custom project names via CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES env var
• Enhanced JSON output: Project-grouped data structure for daily reports
• Improved path parsing: Better extraction of meaningful project names from directory structures
Implementation focuses specifically on the daily command with comprehensive project name handling.
Implementation Details

New _project-names.ts module with intelligent project name parsing and alias support
Enhanced daily data loader with project-aware filtering and grouping
Extended daily command interface with --instances and --project flags
Comprehensive test coverage for project name formatting edge cases
Backward compatible - existing daily command usage patterns unchanged

Usage Examples
# Show daily usage by project
ccusage daily --instances

# Filter daily report to specific project 
ccusage daily --project ccusage

# Custom project aliases for daily reports
export CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES="long-project-name=Short Name"
ccusage daily --instances --json
Closes #137
🤖 Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added the ability to group and filter usage data by project using new command-line options (--instances, --project) in daily reports.
Introduced support for custom project name aliases via the CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable for clearer reporting.
Enhanced JSON and table outputs to display usage breakdowns per project, with improved formatting for project names.



Documentation

Updated user guides and CLI documentation to explain project grouping, filtering, aliasing, and new output formats.
Added detailed examples and usage scenarios for project-level reporting and JSON analysis.



Style

Minor formatting and comment improvements in code for clarity.

nodes.message:
fix(live-monitor): Fix live token count and align default token limit behaviour with docs (#309)

* fix(live-monitor): Fix live token count and align default token limit behaviour with docs

* fix(blocks-json): Fix total token count calculation to include cache

nodes.title: fix(live-monitor): Fix live token count and align default token limit behaviour with docs
nodes.bodyText:
Fixes #288 and #298.
For #288, the issue was simply that the getTotalTokens function was not being used in the live monitor; so the incorrect number was being displayed.
For #298, the issue was that the default behaviour specified in the docs is that the live monitor uses the max token limit from previous blocks. However, the actual default behaviour was to specify no limit at all, and therefore fall back to just showing a 10% progress bar (L226, _live-rendering.ts) for usage and 15% progress bar (L303, _live-rendering.ts).
Before fix:

After fix:

There are some alignment issues in the rendering around the progress bars. However, I do not feel that fixing that issue is necessary for this fix, as it is simply a result of the current formatting choices.
The code for this PR was hand-written, not AI-generated. :-)

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved consistency in handling token limit inputs, so missing or empty values are now treated the same as specifying 'max'.
Enhanced reliability of token count calculations by using a centralized method for determining total tokens.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.24.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​9796 ba69586 Thanks @​simonabadoiu! - Browser Rendering local mode


#​9825 49c85c5 Thanks @​ReppCodes! - Add support for origin_connection_limit to Wrangler
Configure connection limits to Hyperdrive via command line options:

--origin-connection-limit: The (soft) maximum number of connections that Hyperdrive may establish to the origin database.



#​9064 a1181bf Thanks @​sdnts! - Added an event-subscriptions subcommand


Patch Changes


#​9729 1b3a2b7 Thanks @​404Wolf! - Set docker build context to the Dockerfile directory when image_build_context is not explicitly provided


#​9845 dbfa4ef Thanks @​jonboulle! - remove extraneous double spaces from Wrangler help output


#​9811 fc29c31 Thanks @​gpanders! - Fix unauthorized errors on "containers images delete".


#​9813 45497ab Thanks @​gpanders! - Support container image names without account ID


#​9821 a447d67 Thanks @​WillTaylorDev! - Preview Aliases: Force alias generation to meet stricter naming requirements.
For cases where CI is requesting Wrangler to generate the alias based on the branch name, we want a stricter check around the generated alias name in order to avoid version upload failures. If a valid alias name was not able to be generated, we warn and do not provide an alias (avoiding a version upload failure).


#​9840 7c55f9e Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - fix: make sure that the experimental remoteBindings flag is properly handled in getPlatformProxy
There are two issues related to how the experimental remoteBindings flag is handled in getPlatformProxy that are being fixed by this change:

the experimental_remote configuration flag set on service bindings is incorrectly always taken into account, even if remoteBindings is set to false
the experimental_remote configuration flag of all the other bindings is never taken into account (effectively preventing the bindings to be used in remote mode) since the remoteBindings flag is not being properly propagated



#​9801 0bb619a Thanks @​IRCody! - Containers: Fix issue where setting an image URI instead of dockerfile would incorrectly not update the image


#​9872 a727db3 Thanks @​emily-shen! - fix: resolve Dockerfile path relative to the Wrangler config path
This fixes a bug where Wrangler would not be able to find a Dockerfile if a Wrangler config path had been specified with the --config flag.


#​9815 1358034 Thanks @​gpanders! - Remove --json flag from containers and cloudchamber commands (except for "images list")


#​9734 1a58bc3 Thanks @​penalosa! - Make Wrangler warn more loudly if you're missing auth scopes


#​9748 7e3aa1b Thanks @​alsuren! - Internal-only WRANGLER_D1_EXTRA_LOCATION_CHOICES environment variable for enabling D1's testing location hints

nodes.message: chore: release v15.3.1

fix(live-monitor): exclude cache tokens from burn rate indicators (#269)

- Extract rate indicator logic to testable function with comprehensive test coverage

- Move burn rate thresholds to _consts.ts for centralized configuration

- Burn rate display shows total tokens, but HIGH/MODERATE/NORMAL indicators

  use only input+output tokens to maintain consistent thresholds

- Add tokensPerMinuteForIndicator field to BurnRate type

nodes.title: fix(live-monitor): exclude cache tokens from burn rate indicators
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Fixes burn rate indicator display issue introduced in PR #193
Burn rate display shows total tokens (including cache), but HIGH/MODERATE/NORMAL indicators use only input+output tokens to maintain consistent thresholds
Extracts rate indicator logic to testable function with comprehensive boundary value test coverage
Moves burn rate thresholds to _consts.ts for centralized configuration

Changes

Add `tokensPerMinuteForIndicator` field to BurnRate type for separate threshold calculation

Add `BURN_RATE_THRESHOLDS` constants to _consts.ts
Comprehensive test coverage including all boundary values (499, 500, 501, 1000, 1001)

 All existing tests pass
 New rate indicator function has 100% branch coverage
 Burn rate calculation correctly separates cache and non-cache tokens
 Live monitor displays consistent HIGH/MODERATE/NORMAL indicators

Summary by CodeRabbit

Added clearer burn rate indicators ("HIGH", "MODERATE", "NORMAL") based on predefined thresholds for tokens used per minute.
Burn rate calculation now distinguishes between total tokens and tokens used specifically for indicator purposes, improving indicator accuracy.



Tests

#​9535 56dc5c4 Thanks @​penalosa! - In 2023 we announced breakpoint debugging support for Workers, which meant that you could easily debug your Worker code in Wrangler's built-in devtools (accessible via the [d] hotkey) as well as multiple other devtools clients, including VSCode. For most developers, breakpoint debugging via VSCode is the most natural flow, but until now it's required manually configuring a launch.json file, running wrangler dev, and connecting via VSCode's built-in debugger.
Now, using VSCode's built-in JavaScript Debug Terminals, there are just two steps: open a JS debug terminal and run wrangler dev (or vite dev). VSCode will automatically connect to your running Worker (even if you're running multiple Workers at once!) and start a debugging session.

nodes.message:
refactor: Improve the error handling of the PricingFetcher class (#238)

* refactor: Improve the error handling of the PricingFetcher class

* refactor: R -> Result

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: refactor: Improve the error handling of the PricingFetcher class
nodes.bodyText:
Overview
Improved error handling in the PricingFetcher class to implement more robust and consistent error processing. By leveraging the Result type from @praha/byethrow, error propagation and handling have become safer and more predictable.
Key Changes

Introduction of the Result pattern: All asynchronous operations are wrapped in the Result type for explicit error handling
Enhanced type safety: Changed method return types to R.ResultAsync<T, E>
Error propagation: Adopted a functional programming style for error handling using R.pipe()
Other updates: Refactored processes dependent on the PricingFetcher class


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Enhanced error handling and consistency in pricing and data loading features with a new functional approach.
Improved reliability in cost calculation and model pricing retrieval logic.


Chores

Updated development dependencies to the latest versions for improved stability.

nodes.message:
fix: Include cache tokens in live usage token count calculations (#193)

* fix: Include cache tokens in live usage token count calculations

Previously, the live usage monitor and blocks command only counted input and output tokens, excluding cache_creation_input_tokens and cache_read_input_tokens from the total. This caused inaccurate token usage reporting, especially when cache creation tokens (which cost more than input tokens) were significant.

Changes:
- Add getTotalTokens() helper function to sum all four token types
- Update live rendering display to use getTotalTokens() for accurate counts
- Fix burn rate calculation to include cache tokens in tokens/minute metric
- Fix usage projection to include cache tokens in projected totals
- Update blocks command to count cache tokens in all calculations
- Add unit tests verifying cache tokens are included in calculations
- Fix UI alignment issues in live display (SESSION and Models lines)

This ensures users see accurate total token usage that matches their actual costs.

Fixes #179

* refactor: Extract getTotalTokens to shared utilities to eliminate code duplication

- Create _token-utils.ts with shared getTotalTokens function
- Support both raw usage data format (cacheCreationInputTokens) and aggregated format (cacheCreationTokens)
- Remove duplicate implementations from 4 files
- Maintain backward compatibility with re-export in calculate-cost.ts
- Add comprehensive tests for both token formats

Addresses code review feedback about duplication.

* Refactor: Update blocks command to use shared token utilities

- Import getTotalTokens from shared _token-utils.ts
- Remove duplicate helper function
- Maintain consistent token counting across commands

* Refactor: Update calculate-cost to use shared token utilities

- Import getTotalTokens from shared _token-utils.ts
- Add re-export for backward compatibility
- Update TokenData type alias to use AggregatedTokenCounts
- Maintain existing public API while eliminating duplication

* Refactor: Update live rendering to use shared token utilities

- Import getTotalTokens from shared _token-utils.ts
- Remove duplicate helper function
- Fix alignment issues by using consistent token counting
- Maintain consistent live display behavior

* fix: Include cache tokens in burn rate and projection calculations

* chore: format

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: drewcrawford <drewcrawford@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: a-c-m <a-c-m@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: fix: Include cache tokens in live usage token count calculations
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Fixes live usage monitor and blocks command to include all four token types (input, output, cache_creation_input, cache_read_input)
Adds getTotalTokens() helper function to correctly sum all token types
Updates burn rate and projection calculations to include cache tokens

Test plan

 Build the project with bun run build
 Run ./dist/index.js blocks --live to see live monitoring with accurate token counts
 Verify cache tokens are included in the total (should show values >9M tokens if cache tokens are present)
 Run unit tests with bun run test to verify calculations include cache tokens

Fixes #179

Summary by CodeRabbit

Improvements

Enhanced the accuracy of total token count displayed in live rendering and token usage reports.
Improved alignment of session progress, usage, projection bars, and model information for better visual consistency.
Centralized token counting logic for consistent and reliable token usage calculations across the app.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #242 from ryoppippi/docs/update-installation-bunx

docs: emphasize bunx usage and ultra-small bundle size advantage

nodes.title: docs: emphasize bunx usage and ultra-small bundle size advantage
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Update installation documentation to emphasize using bunx over npx for speed
Highlight that installation is optional due to incredibly small bundle size
Add bundle size as a key differentiating feature

Changes
README.md

Reorder installation methods to put bunx first as recommended option
Add inline bundle size badge to emphasize small size
Add tip about bunx speed advantage
Mark local installation as optional
Add feature bullet about ultra-small bundle size

Documentation Site

Add section explaining why no installation is needed
Include performance comparison table for different runtimes
Highlight bundle size optimization as first key feature
Add tips and info boxes for better user guidance

Context
Based on the creator's tweets about ccusage:

Bundle size is quite small, so installation is not necessary
bunx is recommended over npx for massive speed difference
Deno is also an option for security-conscious users

This PR makes these advantages more visible to users discovering ccusage.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated documentation to highlight the ultra-small bundle size of the CLI tool.
Expanded Quick Start and installation instructions with examples for bunx, npx, and deno, recommending bunx for speed.
Added a new section explaining why installation is optional and included a performance comparison of different runtimes.
Clarified and renamed installation sections to emphasize the optional nature of global installation.

- Position it as the first key feature to emphasize importance

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated documentation to highlight the ultra-small bundle size of the CLI tool.
Expanded Quick Start and installation instructions with examples for bunx, npx, and deno, recommending bunx for speed.
Added a new section explaining why installation is optional and included a performance comparison of different runtimes.
Clarified and renamed installation sections to emphasize the optional nature of global installation.

TypeStrong/TypeDoc (typedoc)

Compare Source
Features

TypeDoc now supports resolving relative paths in links to the package directory as belonging to the project, #​2961.
Declarations without comments will now check for comments on their export specifier, #​2964.

Bug Fixes

Classes, variables, and functions exported with export { type X } are now detected and converted as interfaces/type aliases, #​2962.
Improved warning messaging for links to symbols which were resolved, but the symbols were not included in the documentation, #​2967.
Fixed an issue preventing nested documents from being deserialized from TypeDoc's JSON output or used in packages mode, #​2969.

Thanks!

v4.22.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#​7871 f2a8d4a Thanks @​dario-piotrowicz! - add support for assets bindings to getPlatformProxy
this change makes sure that that getPlatformProxy, when the input configuration
file contains an assets field, correctly returns the appropriate asset binding proxy
example:
// wrangler.jsonc
{
	"name": "my-worker",
	"assets": {
		"directory": "./public/",
		"binding": "ASSETS",
	},
}
import { getPlatformProxy } from "wrangler";

const { env, dispose } = await getPlatformProxy();

const text = await (await env.ASSETS.fetch("http://0.0.0.0/file.txt")).text();
console.log(text); // logs the content of file.txt

await dispose();


Patch Changes


#​9717 d2f2f72 Thanks @​nikitassharma! - Containers should default to a "dev" instance type when no instance type is specified in the wrangler config

nodes.bodyText:
This PR contains the following updates:



Package
Type
Update
Change




node (source)
engines
minor
>=20.0.0 -> >=20.19.3




WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

nodejs/node (node)
v20.19.3
Compare Source
v20.19.2
Compare Source
v20.19.1
Compare Source
v20.19.0: 2025-03-13, Version 20.19.0 'Iron' (LTS), @​marco-ippolito
Compare Source
Notable Changes
require(esm) is now enabled by default
Support for loading native ES modules using require() had been available on v20.x under the command line flag --experimental-require-module, and available by default on v22.x and v23.x. In this release, it is now no longer behind a flag on v20.x.
This feature has been tested on v23.x and v22.x, and we are looking for user feedback from v20.x to make more final tweaks before fully stabilizing it. When the Node.js instance encounters a native ES module in require() somewhere outside node_modules for the first time, it will emit an experimental warning unless require() comes from a path that contains node_modules.  If there happens to be any regressions caused by this feature, users can report it to the Node.js issue tracker. Meanwhile this feature can also be disabled using --no-experimental-require-module as a workaround.
With this feature enabled, Node.js will no longer throw ERR_REQUIRE_ESM if require() is used to load a ES module. It can, however, throw ERR_REQUIRE_ASYNC_MODULE if the ES module being loaded or its dependencies contain top-level await. When the ES module is loaded successfully by require(), the returned object will either be a ES module namespace object similar to what's returned by import(), or what gets exported as "module.exports" in the ES module.
Users can check process.features.require_module to see whether require(esm) is enabled in the current Node.js instance. For packages, the "module-sync" exports condition can be used as a way to detect require(esm) support in the current Node.js instance and allow both require() and import to load the same native ES module. See the documentation for more details about this feature.
Contributed by Joyee Cheung in #​55085
Module syntax detection is now enabled by default
Module syntax detection (the --experimental-detect-module flag) is now
enabled by default. Use --no-experimental-detect-module to disable it if
needed.
Syntax detection attempts to run ambiguous files as CommonJS, and if the module
fails to parse as CommonJS due to ES module syntax, Node.js tries again and runs
the file as an ES module.
Ambiguous files are those with a .js or no extension, where the nearest parent
package.json has no "type" field (either "type": "module" or
"type": "commonjs").
Syntax detection should have no performance impact on CommonJS modules, but it
incurs a slight performance penalty for ES modules; add "type": "module" to
the nearest parent package.json file to eliminate the performance cost.
A use case unlocked by this feature is the ability to use ES module syntax in
extensionless scripts with no nearby package.json.
Thanks to Geoffrey Booth for making this work on #​53619.
Other Notable Changes

[285bb4ee14] - crypto: update root certificates to NSS 3.107 (Node.js GitHub Bot) #​56566
[73b5c16684] - (SEMVER-MINOR) worker: add postMessageToThread (Paolo Insogna) #​53682
[de313b2336] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: only emit require(esm) warning under --trace-require-module (Joyee Cheung) #​56194
[4fba01911d] - (SEMVER-MINOR) process: add process.features.require_module (Joyee Cheung) #​55241
[df8a045afe] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: implement the "module-sync" exports condition (Joyee Cheung) #​54648
[f9dc1eaef5] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: add __esModule to require()'d ESM (Joyee Cheung) #​52166

nodes.message:
fix: handle file read errors gracefully in live monitor (#202)

* fix: handle file read errors gracefully in live monitor

* fix: use .catch instead of try-catch block

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: fix: handle file read errors gracefully in live monitor
nodes.bodyText:
When Claude Code's cleanupPeriodDays option triggers automatic deletion of old usage logs, ccusage blocks --live crashes with ENOENT errors. This fix adds error handling to silently skip files that cannot be read, allowing live monitoring to continue uninterrupted.


Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved error handling to ensure the application continues processing files even if some files are unreadable or inaccessible.

Patch Changes


#​9731 75b75f3 Thanks @​gabivlj! - containers: Check for container scopes before running a container command to give a better error

The Workers Containers API was built on top of Cloudchamber, but has now been moved to its own API

Merge pull request #178 from ryoppippi/fix/ogp-logo-format

fix: change OGP image from SVG to PNG for better social media compatibility

nodes.title: fix: change OGP image from SVG to PNG for better social media compatibility
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Changed OGP image format from SVG to PNG in VitePress config
This ensures the logo displays correctly on social media platforms

Problem
Many social platforms (Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn) do not support SVG format for Open Graph Protocol previews, causing the logo to not display properly when sharing links.
Solution
Updated the og:image meta tag to use logo.png instead of logo.svg. The PNG format is universally supported by all major social media platforms.
Test plan

 Deploy changes to production
 Test URL preview on Twitter Card Validator
 Test URL preview on Facebook Sharing Debugger
 Test URL preview on LinkedIn Post Inspector
 Verify logo displays correctly in all platforms


Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated the Open Graph image for improved link previews by switching from an SVG to a PNG file.

refactor: extract live monitoring rendering logic for better code organization (#170)

* Add file structure refactoring plan

Documents the strategy for separating CLI and business logic to improve maintainability and testability

* refactor: Improve technical comments in live monitoring infrastructure

Update comments in _consts.ts and _terminal-utils.ts to be more specific
and technical:

- Frame rate limiting explanation (60fps, flicker prevention)

- DEC sync mode details with reference to double-buffering concepts

- Terminal buffering and alternate screen functionality clarifications

- Remove generic comments, add context for complex technical concepts

* refactor: Extract live rendering logic into dedicated module

Create src/_live-rendering.ts with all rendering logic moved from
commands:

- Frame rate limiting (shouldRenderFrame, delayWithAbort)

- Display rendering (renderActiveBlock, renderWaitingState)

- Layout functions (renderLiveDisplay, renderCompactLiveDisplay)

- Helper functions (formatTokensShort, DETAIL_COLUMN_WIDTHS)

- LiveMonitoringConfig type definition

- Comprehensive in-source tests for all core functions

This separation improves code organization by moving business logic

out of the command layer, making it more testable and reusable.

* refactor: live monitoring command to thin CLI layer

Simplify commands/_blocks.live.ts by moving all rendering logic to
_live-rendering module:

- Remove 400+ lines of rendering code (renderLiveDisplay,
renderCompactLiveDisplay)

- Remove helper functions (formatTokensShort, DETAIL_COLUMN_WIDTHS)

- Remove redundant function definitions

- Keep only process lifecycle, signal management, and terminal setup

- Import all rendering functions from _live-rendering module

File reduced from ~520 lines to ~95 lines while maintaining identical
behavior.

Commands now act as thin orchestration layers, following separation of
concerns.

* refactor: Address PR review feedback for code quality improvements

- Simplify error handling by removing redundant try/catch wrappers

- Reduce code duplication in usage section rendering with const destructuring

- Restore red styling for error messages to maintain consistency

- Replace let with const for immutable value assignment

All changes maintain existing functionality while improving code clarity and reducing side effects.

* fix: Restore correct live monitoring refresh interval behavior

- Remove overly complex shouldRenderFrame abstraction

- Restore inline frame rate limiting from main branch

- Ensure proper 1-second refresh intervals instead of 16ms updates

- Remove unused imports and tests for deleted function

The refresh interval now works correctly: frame rate limiting prevents

excessive rendering while maintaining the configured update interval.

* refactor: Replace hardcoded ANSI escape sequences with named constants

- Add DISABLE_LINE_WRAP and ENABLE_LINE_WRAP constants for line wrap control

- Add ANSI_RESET constant for color reset sequences

- Improve code maintainability and readability

nodes.title: refactor: extract live monitoring rendering logic for better code organization
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors the live monitoring functionality to improve code organization by separating concerns between the CLI layer and business logic.
Changes Made
🏗️ Code Structure Improvements

Extract rendering logic: Move all display logic from `commands/_blocks.live.ts` to new `src/_live-rendering.ts` module
Thin CLI layer: Reduce command file from ~520 lines to ~95 lines, keeping only process lifecycle management
Better separation of concerns: Commands now act as orchestration layers, business logic is isolated and testable

🔧 Code Quality Improvements

Fix terminal buffer management: Ensure buffer is always cleared after flush to prevent duplicate content
Replace hardcoded ANSI sequences: Add named constants for line wrap control and color reset
Improve comment clarity: Replace informal language with precise technical descriptions

📝 Comment Improvements

Update technical comments to be more specific and educational
Add frame rate limiting explanations (60fps, flicker prevention)
Document DEC synchronized output mode with double-buffering concepts
Clarify terminal buffering and alternate screen functionality

🧪 Testing

Add comprehensive in-source tests for all extracted functions
Frame rate limiting tests with AbortSignal handling
Display formatting helper function tests
Delay and abort signal integration tests

📁 File Changes

`src/_live-rendering.ts` (NEW): 483 lines of extracted rendering logic with tests
`src/commands/_blocks.live.ts`: Simplified to 95 lines (was 520+ lines)
`src/_consts.ts`: Improved frame rate limiting comment
`src/_terminal-utils.ts`: Enhanced technical comments, fixed buffer management, added ANSI constants

Benefits

Better maintainability: Logic is separated from CLI concerns
Improved testability: Rendering functions are now independently testable
Reusable components: Display logic can be reused by other parts of the system
Cleaner architecture: Commands focus on process management, modules handle business logic
More robust terminal handling: Fixed buffer clearing and standardized ANSI sequences

Test Results
All 212 tests pass, including 6 new tests for the extracted functionality.
Behavior
⚠️ No functional changes - the live monitoring behavior remains identical. This is purely a structural refactoring with code quality improvements.
Related
Addresses the file structure concerns noted in the codebase where command files were becoming too large and mixing concerns. Also addresses PR review feedback for code quality improvements.

nodes.title: Add Ccusage native app to related-projects.md
nodes.bodyText:
This ccusage project as inspired lots of people.
Who doesn't love to see how much value they are getting from a subscription.
So I decided to build a native app to visualise some of the data from ccusage,
Because why not, and it kinda turned out really well so i've published it.
https://github.com/EthanBarlo/ccusage-app
Its very fresh and its only been tested so far on Macos.
So feel free to test it out, and see if it works on other platforms.
Obviously open to contributions,
And ideas for what charts would be useful.
And theres definitely room for improvement, but here is the first initial version.
Dashboard

Projects

Sessions

It does also show a countdown and some stats on the currently active session as well.
But I don't have one started right now to screenshot.

Settings
To configure the billling date / subscription reset.


Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added "Ccusage App" to the list of desktop applications that use or extend ccusage, highlighting its graphical data visualization capabilities.

nodes.message:
fix(block): Improve `blocks --live` rendering (#167)

* feat(blocks):Improve live rendering

* PR comments

* chore: format _blocks.live.ts to fix prettier issues

---------

Co-authored-by: ryoppippi <1560508+ryoppippi@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.title: Improve `blocks --live` rendering
nodes.bodyText:
I noticed when I wasn't focused on the terminal in Ghostty, the live terminal had some bad flickering. The cursor was also still being shown.

This addresses that by using the alternate screen provided by terminal emulators.
Also collects all writes and flushes them in a single operation.
Enables DEC mode 2026 for atomic screen updates.
It also makes sure the cursor is hidden.
It also caps the refresh rate at 60fps to preserve CPU

NOTE: only tested in Ghostty
NOTE: couldn't figure out how to auto-format, eslint wasn't doing it, so I used prettier which may have caused too many changes

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Improved terminal output handling with synchronized output mode to reduce flicker and screen tearing during live updates.
Added support for alternate screen buffer, enhancing the live monitoring display experience.
Introduced frame rate limiting to optimize rendering frequency and improve performance.



Bug Fixes

Enhanced error handling to ensure terminal state is properly restored and messages are displayed correctly.



Style

Refined terminal UI formatting for clearer, smoother, and more consistent rendering during live monitoring.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #155 from ryoppippi/refactor/remove-redundant-patterns

refactor: remove redundant library wrapper patterns

nodes.title: refactor: remove redundant library wrapper patterns
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Remove redundant TERMINAL_CONTROL wrapper that simply re-exported ansi-escapes functions
Replace manual object recreation in createTotalsObject with spread operator
Add comprehensive JSDoc comments for better code understanding

Benefits

Reduced bundle size: Eliminates unnecessary wrapper functions
Better performance: Direct library usage without extra function calls
Improved maintainability: Less redundant code to maintain
Better documentation: Clear comments explaining non-obvious usage patterns

Changes

terminal-utils: Remove TERMINAL_CONTROL wrapper, use ansi-escapes directly
calculate-cost: Use spread operator instead of manual object property recreation
JSDoc improvements: Add detailed comments for functions that need explanation

Testing

✅ All existing tests pass
✅ Commands (daily, blocks) work correctly
✅ Live monitoring functionality preserved
✅ Type checking passes
✅ Linting passes

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #152 from ryoppippi/update-typedoc

chore(docs): modernize typedoc tooling with bun and tinyglobby

nodes.title: chore(docs): modernize typedoc tooling with bun and tinyglobby
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
• Replace fast-glob with tinyglobby for better performance and smaller bundle size
• Convert Node.js scripts to Bun for faster execution and built-in TypeScript support
• Update typedoc dependency to latest version (^0.28.5)
• Modernize API documentation generation pipeline
Changes

Dependencies: Replaced fast-glob with tinyglobby, updated typedoc to ^0.28.5
Scripting: Converted update-api-index.mjs to update-api-index.ts with Bun runtime
Build Pipeline: Updated package.json scripts to use Bun for API documentation generation
TypeDoc Config: Updated import statements to use tinyglobby instead of fast-glob

Benefits

Faster script execution with Bun native TypeScript support
Smaller dependency footprint with tinyglobby
More consistent tooling across the project
Up-to-date TypeDoc with latest features and fixes


Summary by CodeRabbit

Chores

Updated documentation build scripts and dependencies to use Bun for script execution.
Replaced file globbing and file system utilities with Bun-compatible alternatives.
Upgraded and replaced development dependencies to improve tooling compatibility.

nodes.message: chore: release v15.1.0

Merge pull request #140 from ryoppippi/docs/vitepress-setup

docs: migrate to VitePress documentation system

nodes.title: docs: migrate to VitePress documentation system
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR migrates the project documentation from simple markdown files to a comprehensive VitePress-based documentation system with the following key improvements:
• Interactive Documentation Site: Replace static markdown with searchable, navigable documentation
• API Documentation: Automated TypeDoc integration for complete API reference
• User Guides: Comprehensive guides for all features (daily reports, live monitoring, MCP server, etc.)
• Modern Deployment: Cloudflare Pages integration with automated builds
• Better Organization: Structured navigation and improved content organization
Changes Made
Documentation Structure

✅ Added VitePress configuration and theme setup
✅ Created comprehensive user guides for all features
✅ Integrated TypeDoc for automated API documentation
✅ Added Cloudflare Pages deployment configuration
✅ Removed outdated image assets and replaced with organized public assets

Project Configuration

✅ Updated package.json with documentation dependencies and scripts
✅ Updated ESLint configuration for documentation files
✅ Added TypeDoc configuration for API documentation generation

Code Enhancements

✅ Enhanced source code with documentation-friendly improvements
✅ Updated project documentation (CLAUDE.md, README.md)
✅ Improved code organization and documentation support

Documentation Features
User Guides

Getting Started: Installation and basic usage
Daily Reports: Detailed usage tracking by day
Monthly Reports: Long-term usage analysis
Session Reports: Per-session usage breakdown

nodes.message:
fix: exclude docs directory from ESLint

Exclude docs/** from ESLint to avoid build-dependent linting issues:

- docs directory contains generated content and VitePress config

- TypeDoc sidebar and API files are generated during build

- Prevents CI lint failures when docs are not yet built

Merge pull request #138 from lapfelix/main

Fix block start time flooring to nearest hour

nodes.title: Fix block start time flooring to nearest hour
nodes.bodyText:
Fixes issue where blocks would start at exact session times instead of hour boundaries
Add test to verify block start times are correctly floored

Fixes #133



Before
After










These screenshots were taken at 7:19 PM so the correct remaining time, considering Claude says it resets at 9:00 PM, is 1h 41m.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Session block start times are now consistently aligned to the beginning of the hour, improving accuracy in session grouping.


Tests

Added a test case to verify correct alignment of session block start times to the nearest hour.

Merge pull request #126 from a-c-m/main

feat(blocks): add live monitoring mode with real-time usage dashboard

nodes.title: feat(blocks): add live monitoring mode with real-time usage dashboard
nodes.bodyText:
Add --live flag to blocks command for real-time monitoring
Display session progress, token usage, burn rate, and cost projections
Implement efficient incremental data loading to minimize file I/O
Default to 'max' token limit when not specified in live mode
Support customizable refresh intervals (1-60 seconds)
Add professional box-based terminal UI with proper alignment
Extract live monitoring logic to dedicated blocks-live.ts module
Add LiveMonitor class for efficient file change tracking

The live mode provides a dashboard that updates every few seconds showing:

Current session progress with time remaining
Token usage with burn rate indicators (normal/moderate/high)
Cost projections to help users stay within limits
Model information for the active session

Example usage:
bun run start blocks --live bun run start blocks --live --token-limit 60000 bun run start blocks --live --refresh-interval 5
BREAKING CHANGE: None

nodes.title: feat(blocks): add live monitoring mode with real-time usage dashboard

Add --live flag to blocks command for real-time monitoring
Display session progress, token usage, burn rate, and cost projections
Implement efficient incremental data loading to minimize file I/O
Default to 'max' token limit when not specified in live mode
Support customizable refresh intervals (1-60 seconds)

nodes.message: chore: release v14.1.2

Merge pull request #129 from nicobailon/fix-claude-path

fix: use getClaudePaths for multi-directory support

nodes.title: fix: use getClaudePaths for multi-directory support
nodes.bodyText:
Remove claudePath parameter from data loading functions in all commands
This allows the data loader to check multiple Claude directories automatically
Supports both ~/.config/claude and ~/.claude paths
Fixes 'No Claude usage data found' error when data exists in alternate locations


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Simplified data loading and mismatch detection by removing explicit usage of the default Claude path across several commands. The system now defaults to implicit or no path, streamlining internal processes. No changes to user-facing features or command usage.

nodes.message: chore: release v14.1.1

Merge pull request #128 from zhiyue/fix/offline-flag-blocks-command

fix: add offline flag support to blocks command

nodes.title: fix: add offline flag support to blocks command
nodes.bodyText:
Description
This PR fixes the --offline flag not working for the blocks command.
Problem
The --offline flag works correctly for commands like monthly but does not work for the blocks command. When running ccusage blocks --offline, the command still attempts to fetch pricing data from the API instead of using cached data.
Root Cause
The issue occurs in two places:

In src/commands/blocks.ts, the offline parameter was not being passed to loadSessionBlockData()
In src/data-loader.ts, the loadSessionBlockData() function was not passing the offline parameter to the PricingFetcher constructor

Solution

Added offline: ctx.values.offline to the options object passed to loadSessionBlockData() in src/commands/blocks.ts
Changed new PricingFetcher() to new PricingFetcher(options?.offline) in src/data-loader.ts

This matches the implementation in other commands like monthly which correctly handle the offline flag.
Testing
After this fix:

ccusage blocks --offline now correctly uses cached pricing data
ccusage blocks --no-offline (or without the flag) fetches fresh pricing data
Behavior is now consistent with other commands

Fixes #127
🤖 Generated with Claude Code
Co-Authored-By: Claude noreply@anthropic.com

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Improved support for offline mode during session block data loading, enabling better handling of pricing data when offline functionality is active.

and loadSessionBlockData() was not passing it to PricingFetcher constructor.

This fix ensures the blocks command respects the --offline flag like other commands do.

Fixes #127

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Problem
The --offline flag works correctly for commands like monthly but does not work for the blocks command. When running ccusage blocks --offline, the command still attempts to fetch pricing data from the API instead of using cached data.

In src/commands/blocks.ts, the offline parameter was not being passed to loadSessionBlockData()

Added offline: ctx.values.offline to the options object passed to loadSessionBlockData() in src/commands/blocks.ts
Changed new PricingFetcher() to new PricingFetcher(options?.offline) in src/data-loader.ts

This matches the implementation in other commands like monthly which correctly handle the offline flag.

nodes.message: chore: release v14.1.0

Merge pull request #125 from ryoppippi/feat/xdg-basedir-support

feat: Add XDG Base Directory Specification support for config paths

nodes.title: feat: Add XDG Base Directory Specification support for config paths
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Replace hardcoded ~/.config paths with XDG-compliant configuration directory resolution
Add xdg-basedir dependency for proper XDG Base Directory Specification support
Maintain backward compatibility with existing ~/.claude directory structure
Update all path resolution logic across data-loader, debug, and constants modules

Changes Made
Dependencies

Added `xdg-basedir` as dev dependency for XDG directory specification compliance

Constants Module (`_consts.ts`)

Import `xdgConfig` from xdg-basedir library
Update `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` to use `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` when available, fallback to `~/.config/claude`
Add `XDG_CONFIG_DIR` constant for future extensibility
Reorder constant definitions to fix dependency order issues

Data Loader Module (`data-loader.ts`)

Replace hardcoded path construction with XDG-aware constants
Use `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` directly in `getClaudePaths()` function
Update error messages to show XDG-resolved paths
Maintain full backward compatibility with existing ~/.claude directory

Debug Module (`debug.ts`)

Replace `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH` with `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` for default path resolution
Remove unused `USER_HOME_DIR` import
Use XDG-aware path resolution for Claude directory detection

Benefits

Standards Compliance: Follows XDG Base Directory Specification for proper Linux/Unix config directory handling
User Control: Respects `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` environment variable when set by users
Backward Compatibility: Continues to work with existing ~/.claude installations
Cross-Platform: Works consistently across different Unix-like systems
Future-Proof: Provides foundation for other XDG directory types (data, cache, etc.)

Testing

All existing tests pass without modification
XDG path resolution tested in multiple scenarios
Backward compatibility verified with legacy ~/.claude directories
Environment variable handling tested for `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` and `XDG_CONFIG_HOME`

Migration Impact
No breaking changes - existing users will see no difference in behavior unless they specifically set `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` environment variable.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Improved configuration directory handling to support XDG config directories, providing better compatibility with various operating systems.



Chores

Added "xdg-basedir" as a development dependency for enhanced config path management.



Refactor

Updated internal logic to use dynamic configuration paths based on the XDG standard, replacing hardcoded paths and centralizing home directory access.

nodes.message:
docs: add export rules to CLAUDE.md for future reference

Document important principles for code organization:

- Only export constants/functions/types that are used by other modules

- Keep internal/private items non-exported to minimize public API surface

- Always add dependencies as devDependencies unless explicitly requested

This ensures consistent code organization and prevents unnecessary exports that clutter the module interface.

nodes.message:
fix(types): add explicit TypeScript type annotations and improve constant organization

- Add explicit string type annotations to USER_HOME_DIR and XDG_CONFIG_DIR to fix unsafe assignment warnings reported by CodeRabbit

- Extract XDG_CONFIG_DIR as internal constant and use it in DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH to avoid code duplication as suggested by Copilot

- Reorder constants to fix dependency order and ensure XDG_CONFIG_DIR is defined before use

- Make XDG_CONFIG_DIR non-exported since it is only used internally within _consts.ts

nodes.message: chore: release v14.0.0

Merge pull request #118 from adhishthite/main

feat(ui): Improve responsiveness and model display in usage reports

nodes.title: feat(ui): Improve responsiveness and model display in usage reports
nodes.bodyText:
🖥️ Improve Table Responsiveness and Model Display
📋 Summary
This PR significantly improves the user experience for viewing Claude Code usage reports on smaller terminal sizes by implementing responsive table layouts and enhanced model formatting.
🎯 Key Features
1. Smart Responsive Tables

Compact Mode: Automatically activates when terminal width < 100 characters
Column Prioritization: Hides less critical columns (Cache Create, Cache Read, Total Tokens) in compact mode
Essential Data: Always shows Date, Models, Input, Output, and Cost (USD)
User Guidance: Clear messaging when in compact mode

2. Enhanced Model Display

Multiline Format: Models now display as bulleted lists instead of comma-separated text
Space Efficient: Significantly reduces horizontal space usage
Professional Appearance: Clean • model-name format for better readability

3. Universal Support

All Commands: Works across daily, monthly, session, and blocks commands
Seamless Switching: Automatically adapts based on terminal width
Consistent Experience: Same behavior across all report types


🔧 Technical Implementation
New Components

ResponsiveTable class with compact mode detection
formatModelsDisplayMultiline() function for bulleted model lists
Automatic terminal width detection using COLUMNS environment variable
Smart column filtering based on available space

Enhanced Features

Compact mode threshold configuration (default: 100 characters)
Dynamic table head and column alignment switching
Comprehensive test coverage for new functionality


📸 Visual Comparison
Before

After (Wide Terminal)

After (Compact Mode - 70 columns)


✅ Quality Assurance

✅ Comprehensive Tests: Added 5 new test cases for multiline formatting
✅ Code Quality: Passes ESLint, TypeScript checks, and existing test suite
✅ Backward Compatibility: All existing functionality preserved
✅ Cross-Platform: Works on all terminal sizes and operating systems


🎉 User Benefits

Better Mobile/Small Screen Experience: Reports are now readable on narrow terminals
Cleaner Model Display: Professional bulleted lists instead of cramped comma-separated text
Space Efficiency: Models column uses significantly less horizontal space
Smart Adaptation: Automatically shows the best layout for current terminal size
Clear Guidance: Users know exactly how to see full data when needed


This enhancement makes Claude Code usage reports accessible and readable regardless of terminal size, while maintaining a professional appearance and all existing functionality.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Tables now automatically switch to a compact mode when the terminal window is narrow, improving readability on smaller screens.
Model lists in usage reports are now displayed in a multiline, bulleted format for enhanced clarity.



Enhancements

Informational messages guide users to expand their terminal width to view additional metrics when in compact mode.

nodes.message:
docs: add comprehensive documentation for responsive table features

- Document responsive table behavior and compact mode functionality

- Add visual examples for both wide and narrow terminal displays

- Update feature list with new responsive capabilities

- Include guidance on terminal width requirements

The documentation now clearly explains how the responsive tables

work and provides visual examples of the output in different

terminal sizes, helping users understand the feature benefits.

Co-authored-by: adhishthite <adhishthite@users.noreply.github.com>

Automatic terminal width detection using COLUMNS environment variable
Smart column filtering based on available space

Enhanced Features

Compact mode threshold configuration (default: 100 characters)
Dynamic table head and column alignment switching
Comprehensive test coverage for new functionality


📸 Visual Comparison
Before

After (Wide Terminal)

After (Compact Mode - 70 columns)


✅ Quality Assurance

✅ Comprehensive Tests: Added 5 new test cases for multiline formatting
✅ Code Quality: Passes ESLint, TypeScript checks, and existing test suite
✅ Backward Compatibility: All existing functionality preserved
✅ Cross-Platform: Works on all terminal sizes and operating systems


🎉 User Benefits

Better Mobile/Small Screen Experience: Reports are now readable on narrow terminals
Cleaner Model Display: Professional bulleted lists instead of cramped comma-separated text
Space Efficiency: Models column uses significantly less horizontal space
Smart Adaptation: Automatically shows the best layout for current terminal size
Clear Guidance: Users know exactly how to see full data when needed


This enhancement makes Claude Code usage reports accessible and readable regardless of terminal size, while maintaining a professional appearance and all existing functionality.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Tables now automatically switch to a compact mode when the terminal window is narrow, improving readability on smaller screens.
Model lists in usage reports are now displayed in a multiline, bulleted format for enhanced clarity.



Enhancements

Informational messages guide users to expand their terminal width to view additional metrics when in compact mode.
