nodes.title: feat(ui): Improve responsiveness and model display in usage reports
nodes.bodyText:
🖥️ Improve Table Responsiveness and Model Display
📋 Summary
This PR significantly improves the user experience for viewing Claude Code usage reports on smaller terminal sizes by implementing responsive table layouts and enhanced model formatting.
🎯 Key Features
1. Smart Responsive Tables

Compact Mode: Automatically activates when terminal width < 100 characters
Column Prioritization: Hides less critical columns (Cache Create, Cache Read, Total Tokens) in compact mode
Essential Data: Always shows Date, Models, Input, Output, and Cost (USD)
User Guidance: Clear messaging when in compact mode

2. Enhanced Model Display

Multiline Format: Models now display as bulleted lists instead of comma-separated text
Space Efficient: Significantly reduces horizontal space usage
Professional Appearance: Clean • model-name format for better readability

3. Universal Support

All Commands: Works across daily, monthly, session, and blocks commands
Seamless Switching: Automatically adapts based on terminal width
Consistent Experience: Same behavior across all report types


🔧 Technical Implementation
New Components

ResponsiveTable class with compact mode detection
formatModelsDisplayMultiline() function for bulleted model lists
Automatic terminal width detection using COLUMNS environment variable
Smart column filtering based on available space

Enhanced Features

Compact mode threshold configuration (default: 100 characters)
Dynamic table head and column alignment switching
Comprehensive test coverage for new functionality

✅ Cross-Platform: Works on all terminal sizes and operating systems

feat: Support multiple Claude data directories to handle v1.0.30+ path change

nodes.title: feat: Support multiple Claude data directories to handle v1.0.30+ path change
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
fixes: #121
This PR adds support for multiple Claude data directories to handle different Claude Code installations and the breaking change where logs moved from ~/.claude to ~/.config/claude.
Key Features
• Multiple Path Support: Automatically searches both ~/.config/claude/projects/ (new default) and ~/.claude/projects/ (old default)
• Environment Variable: Set CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR to specify custom path(s) - supports comma-separated multiple paths
• Data Aggregation: Usage data from all valid directories is automatically combined
• Backward Compatibility: Existing configurations continue to work without changes
Implementation Highlights
• Core Functionality: New getClaudePaths() function with path normalization and duplicate removal
• Environment Support: CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR accepts single or comma-separated multiple paths
• Robust Testing: Comprehensive test coverage with CI improvements for multiple path scenarios
• Code Quality: Refactored imports to use .ts extensions, replaced custom utilities with @antfu/utils
Commit Organization
Each commit represents a logical grouping:

Constants: Core constants for multiple path support
Core Implementation: getClaudePaths function and data loading updates
Code Quality: Dependency updates and import standardization
Testing Infrastructure: CI improvements for multiple path testing
Documentation: Updated README and CLAUDE.md with usage examples

Breaking Changes
None - this is fully backward compatible. Existing users will see no changes in behavior.
Migration Path
• No Action Required: Existing ~/.claude installations continue working
• Optional: Set CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable for custom paths
• Future-Proof: New ~/.config/claude installations are automatically detected
Test Plan

 Existing functionality works unchanged
 Multiple paths are correctly detected and combined
 Environment variable support works for single and multiple paths
 Path normalization prevents duplicates
 CI tests pass with both directory structures
 Backward compatibility maintained for deprecated functions


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for detecting and aggregating Claude Code usage data from multiple directories, including both new and legacy default locations.
Users can now specify custom data directories using the CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable, supporting multiple comma-separated paths.



Documentation

Updated documentation and README to explain multi-directory support and new configuration options.



Chores

Enhanced CI workflow to create both legacy and new default data directories for testing.
Added a new development dependency for utilities.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #124 from ryoppippi/refactor/underscore-prefix-internal-files

refactor: rename internal files from .internal. to _ prefix

nodes.title: refactor: rename internal files from .internal. to _ prefix
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
• Rename all .internal. files to use _ prefix for better file organization
• Update tsdown configuration to exclude _*.ts files instead of *.internal.ts
• Update all import statements throughout the codebase
• Add documentation for the new naming convention
Changes

src/macro.internal.ts → src/_macro.ts
src/shared-args.internal.ts → src/_shared-args.ts
src/consts.internal.ts → src/_consts.ts
src/session-blocks.internal.ts → src/_session-blocks.ts
src/types.internal.ts → src/_types.ts
src/utils.internal.ts → src/_utils.ts
Updated tsdown.config.ts entry patterns with comments
Updated CLAUDE.md naming conventions documentation

Benefits

Internal files are grouped together when listing files alphabetically
Follows common Node.js/TypeScript convention of _ prefix for internal files
Shorter file names and cleaner imports
Better separation of public vs internal modules

Test plan

 Build passes: bun run build
 Type check passes: bun typecheck
 Linting passes: ESLint MCP server
 Tests pass: bun run test
 All imports resolve correctly


Summary by CodeRabbit


Documentation

Updated documentation to clarify naming conventions for internal files, specifying the use of an underscore prefix.



Chores

Updated import paths throughout the project to use underscore-prefixed filenames for internal modules.
Adjusted build configuration to explicitly exclude test files and internal files (with underscore prefix) from the build process.



No functional changes were made to the application's behavior.

nodes.title: feat: replace PNG logo with SVG for better scalability
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Replace the PNG logo with SVG format for improved scalability and better handling.
Changes

Replace docs/logo.png with docs/logo.svg (vector format)
Update README.md logo reference from PNG to SVG

Background
Following the X conversation (https://x.com/ryoppippi/status/1935394423082496432) about SVG format benefits. SVG provides better handling and scalability compared to PNG format.
NoteDue to CDN distribution timing, the SVG might not be immediately available after merge. If there are any issues with CDN delivery, we can temporarily reference the GitHub raw URL directly until CDN catches up.


Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated logo image in README from PNG to SVG format, maintaining size and alt text.

nodes.title: docs: improve README layout
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
After adding the logo in #112, the README header feels slightly cramped. This PR follows Next.js's header structure pattern to improve visual hierarchy and spacing.
Personal preference
This is my personal preference for layout - feel free to reject if you disagree!
Reference: Next.js approach
For example. Next.js follows this pattern in their README:

Brand logo
Library name as <h1>
Separator/spacing
Badge row


Visual comparison



Before
After










Summary by CodeRabbit
Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Improved the layout of the README's top section by combining the logo and title within a centered container and updating the heading style for better visual grouping.
Formatted podcast links for clarity and adjusted spacing in the sponsors section for cleaner presentation.

docs: use jsdelivr CDN for all image URLs in README

Replace relative and GitHub raw URLs with jsdelivr CDN URLs for better performance and reliability:

- docs/logo.png → https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/ryoppippi/ccusage@main/docs/logo.png

- GitHub raw screenshot URL → https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/ryoppippi/ccusage@main/docs/screenshot.png

- GitHub raw MCP desktop image URL → https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/ryoppippi/ccusage@main/docs/mcp-claude-desktop.avif

This change ensures consistent CDN delivery for all images and removes dependency on GitHub raw content serving.

docs: add ccusage Raycast Extension to Related Projects

nodes.title: docs: add ccusage Raycast Extension to Related Projects
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add the ccusage Raycast Extension to the Related Projects section in README.md
Provides users with easy access to a Raycast extension for viewing Claude Code usage reports

Details
This PR adds a new entry to the Related Projects section for the ccusage Raycast Extension. The extension allows users to view Claude Code usage reports directly within Raycast, providing a convenient integration for Raycast users.
The addition follows the same format as the existing macOS menu bar app entry, maintaining consistency in the documentation.
Related

Extension URL: https://www.raycast.com/nyatinte/ccusage
Extension created by: @nyatinte

Thank you @ryoppippi for creating such an awesome tool and for all your help and support during the Raycast extension development process! 🙏

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added a new related project, "ccusage Raycast Extension," to the README's Related Projects section.

nodes.message: chore: release v12.4.0

Merge pull request #111 from ryoppippi/consts

refactor: consolidate scattered constants into centralized consts.internal.ts

nodes.title: refactor: consolidate scattered constants into centralized consts.internal.ts
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Consolidate scattered constants from multiple files into a centralized consts.internal.ts
Add comprehensive JSDoc documentation for all constants
Use context-specific naming conventions (e.g., BLOCKS_, DEBUG_, MCP_) for clarity
Replace hardcoded values with named constants throughout the codebase
Maintain single source of truth for configuration values

Changes Made
Constants Consolidated
Time/Duration Constants:

DEFAULT_RECENT_DAYS = 3 - Recent days filtering across commands

UI/Display Constants:

BLOCKS_WARNING_THRESHOLD = 0.8 - Usage warning threshold (80%)
BLOCKS_COMPACT_WIDTH_THRESHOLD = 120 - Terminal width for compact mode
BLOCKS_DEFAULT_TERMINAL_WIDTH = 120 - Fallback terminal width

Threshold/Tolerance Constants:

DEBUG_MATCH_THRESHOLD_PERCENT = 0.1 - Cost matching tolerance for debug validation

File/Path Constants:

DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH = ".claude" - Claude data directory name
CLAUDE_PROJECTS_DIR_NAME = "projects" - Projects directory name
USAGE_DATA_GLOB_PATTERN = "**/*.jsonl" - JSONL file search pattern

Network/System Constants:

MCP_DEFAULT_PORT = 8080 - MCP server default port
USER_HOME_DIR - Centralized home directory access

Files Modified

src/consts.internal.ts - New centralized constants file
src/commands/blocks.ts - Updated to use centralized constants
src/commands/mcp.ts - Updated to use MCP_DEFAULT_PORT
src/data-loader.ts - Updated to use path and file constants
src/debug.ts - Updated to use debug threshold constant
src/session-blocks.internal.ts - Removed duplicate constants

Benefits

Single Source of Truth: All configuration values in one place
Better Maintainability: Easy to update values across the entire codebase
Clear Naming: Context-specific prefixes make usage intent obvious
Documentation: JSDoc explains purpose and usage for each constant
Type Safety: No more magic numbers/strings scattered throughout code

Test Plan

 All existing tests pass (182/182)
 TypeScript compilation succeeds
 ESLint formatting completes without errors
 No functional changes - pure refactoring
 Constants maintain same values as before consolidation


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Centralized configuration values and path definitions by replacing hardcoded constants and strings with shared constants across the application.
Updated descriptions and behaviors to dynamically reflect these centralized values.


Chores

Improved maintainability by consolidating default settings, directory names, file patterns, and thresholds into a single internal module.

nodes.message:
refactor: consolidate network and path constants with centralized naming

- Add MCP_DEFAULT_PORT constant for MCP server default port (8080)
- Add USER_HOME_DIR constant for centralized home directory access
- Update commands/mcp.ts to use MCP_DEFAULT_PORT for consistent port handling
- Replace homedir() calls with USER_HOME_DIR in data-loader.ts and debug.ts
- Keep homedir import in data-loader.ts for test usage (tree-shaken in production)
- Add comprehensive JSDoc explaining network and system path constants

This consolidation provides centralized access to system paths and network
configuration, eliminating scattered hardcoded values across the application.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #109 from ryoppippi/brand

feat: enhance type safety with Zod branded types and performance optimizations

nodes.title: feat: enhance type safety with Zod branded types and performance optimizations
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This comprehensive implementation introduces branded types for enhanced type safety while maintaining performance through strategic optimizations.
🎯 Key Features
Branded Types Implementation

Core Identifiers: ModelName, SessionId, ProjectPath, Version for compile-time safety
Date Types: DailyDate, ActivityDate, MonthlyDate, ISOTimestamp for temporal data validation
Helper Functions: Type-safe constructors with validation (createModelName, createActivityDate, etc.)
Type Safety: Prevents runtime errors and improves IDE support

Performance Optimizations

Smart Parsing: Use type assertions for already-validated data in hot paths
Loop Optimization: Avoid expensive regex validation in array mapping operations
Balanced Approach: Maintain type safety while optimizing critical performance paths

Backward Compatibility

Legacy Support: Relaxed model name validation for synthetic/unknown models
Data Migration: Seamless compatibility with existing JSONL data formats
Non-breaking: All existing functionality preserved

📊 Performance Analysis
Bundle Size Impact

Main Branch: 919.38 kB
Current Branch: 922.96 kB
Difference: +3.58 kB (+0.4%) - minimal overhead for comprehensive type safety

Runtime Performance (hyperfine benchmarks, offline mode)
Daily Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     612.7 ms ± 20.9 ms
Range (min … max):   590.7 ms … 684.4 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     631.3 ms ± 7.0 ms
Range (min … max):   618.5 ms … 645.3 ms
Result: ~3% slower (18.6ms difference)
```
Session Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     606.0 ms ± 9.8 ms
Range (min … max):   593.1 ms … 630.4 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     620.7 ms ± 6.0 ms
Range (min … max):   608.5 ms … 630.9 ms
Result: ~2.4% slower (14.7ms difference)
```
Monthly Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     607.9 ms ± 6.4 ms
Range (min … max):   597.5 ms … 618.9 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean ± σ):     622.9 ms ± 7.4 ms
Range (min … max):   611.1 ms … 637.7 ms
Result: ~2.5% slower (15.0ms difference)
```
Performance Trade-off Analysis

Impact: ~3% performance decrease (~15-20ms average)
User Experience: Imperceptible difference (< 100ms threshold)
Benefits: Significant compile-time safety, better IDE support, runtime error prevention
Conclusion: Excellent trade-off for enhanced development experience

🔧 Technical Implementation
Before (Performance Issues)
```typescript
// Expensive regex validation in loops
modelsUsed: modelsUsed.map(createModelName),  // Validates each model with regex
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort().map(createVersion),  // Validates each version
modelName: createModelName(modelName),  // Individual validation calls
```
After (Optimized Approach)
```typescript
// Type assertions for already-validated data
modelsUsed: modelsUsed as ModelName[],  // Direct assertion, no re-validation
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort() as Version[],  // Direct assertion
modelName: modelName as ModelName,  // Direct assertion in aggregation
```
Safety Guarantees
✅ Input Validation: All data validated by Zod schemas during initial JSONL parsing
✅ Type Safety: Branded types prevent identifier mix-ups at compile time
✅ Runtime Safety: Type assertions only used after validation, not before
✅ IDE Support: Enhanced autocomplete, refactoring, and error detection
📝 Key Changes
Core Files Modified

src/types.internal.ts: Comprehensive branded type system with Zod schemas
src/data-loader.ts: Performance-optimized parsing with branded type integration
src/calculate-cost.ts: Updated test data with proper branded type constructors

New Branded Types
```typescript
type ModelName = string & { readonly brand: ModelName };
type SessionId = string & { readonly brand: SessionId };
type ActivityDate = string & { readonly brand: ActivityDate }; // YYYY-MM-DD
type DailyDate = string & { readonly brand: DailyDate };   // YYYY-MM-DD
type Version = string & { readonly brand: Version };       // SemVer format
```
Validation Strategy

Strict Validation: Input parsing from JSONL files
Type Assertions: Internal data transformations and aggregations
Helper Functions: Safe construction with validation when needed

🧪 Test Plan

 Type Checking: All TypeScript compilation passes without errors
 Unit Tests: All 182 tests pass successfully
 Performance Testing: Comprehensive hyperfine benchmarking across all commands
 Bundle Analysis: Size impact verification (+0.4% acceptable)
 Compatibility Testing: Verified with existing data including synthetic model names
 Offline Testing: All benchmarks run with --offline flag to avoid network interference
 Integration Testing: End-to-end functionality verified

💡 Benefits
Developer Experience

Type Safety: Compile-time validation prevents common string identifier errors
IDE Support: Better autocomplete, navigation, and refactoring capabilities
Debugging: Clear type information makes issues easier to identify and fix
Maintainability: Self-documenting code with explicit type contracts

Runtime Benefits

Error Prevention: Branded types catch identifier mix-ups before they cause issues
Data Integrity: Ensured format consistency across the application
Performance Balance: Optimizations where they matter most (hot paths)

Future-Proofing

Extensibility: Easy to add new branded types for additional domain concepts
Migration Path: Smooth upgrade path for existing data and usage patterns
Type Evolution: Foundation for more advanced type safety features

🔄 Migration Notes
This change is backward compatible - no user action required:

Existing JSONL data continues to work unchanged
All CLI commands maintain identical behavior
API contracts preserved for programmatic usage
Performance characteristics remain within acceptable bounds


Trade-off Summary: ~3% performance cost for significant type safety improvements - excellent value proposition for a development tool prioritizing reliability and maintainability.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced enhanced validation and type safety for key data fields, including dates, identifiers, and model names.
Added helper functions for safely creating and validating these branded data types.



Refactor

Updated internal data handling to use stricter schemas and branded types, improving consistency and reliability across the application.



Tests

Adjusted test data to conform to the new type-safe schemas and branded types.

nodes.message:
test: update test data to use branded type constructors

**Test Data Standardization:**
- Replace direct string assignments with proper branded type constructors
- Use createModelName() for all Claude model references in tests
- Use createActivityDate() for lastActivity fields (YYYY-MM-DD format)
- Use createDailyDate(), createSessionId(), createProjectPath() in test scenarios

**Type Safety in Tests:**
- Ensure all test data validates through branded type schemas
- Update test expectations to work with branded types
- Maintain test coverage while enforcing type constraints

**Model Updates:**
- Update test models to use current Claude 4 naming (claude-sonnet-4-20250514, claude-opus-4-20250514)
- Ensure backward compatibility testing with various model name formats

This ensures tests validate the same type constraints as production code.

```typescript
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort().map(createVersion),  // Validates each version
modelName: createModelName(modelName),  // Individual validation calls
```
After (Optimized Approach)
```typescript
// Type assertions for already-validated data
modelsUsed: modelsUsed as ModelName[],  // Direct assertion, no re-validation
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort() as Version[],  // Direct assertion
modelName: modelName as ModelName,  // Direct assertion in aggregation
```
Safety Guarantees
✅ Input Validation: All data validated by Zod schemas during initial JSONL parsing
✅ Type Safety: Branded types prevent identifier mix-ups at compile time
✅ Runtime Safety: Type assertions only used after validation, not before
✅ IDE Support: Enhanced autocomplete, refactoring, and error detection
📝 Key Changes
Core Files Modified

src/types.internal.ts: Comprehensive branded type system with Zod schemas
src/data-loader.ts: Performance-optimized parsing with branded type integration
src/calculate-cost.ts: Updated test data with proper branded type constructors

New Branded Types
```typescript
type ModelName = string & { readonly brand: ModelName };
type SessionId = string & { readonly brand: SessionId };
type ActivityDate = string & { readonly brand: ActivityDate }; // YYYY-MM-DD
type DailyDate = string & { readonly brand: DailyDate };   // YYYY-MM-DD
type Version = string & { readonly brand: Version };       // SemVer format
```
Validation Strategy

Strict Validation: Input parsing from JSONL files
Type Assertions: Internal data transformations and aggregations
Helper Functions: Safe construction with validation when needed

🧪 Test Plan

 Type Checking: All TypeScript compilation passes without errors
 Unit Tests: All 182 tests pass successfully
 Performance Testing: Comprehensive hyperfine benchmarking across all commands
 Bundle Analysis: Size impact verification (+0.4% acceptable)
 Compatibility Testing: Verified with existing data including synthetic model names
 Offline Testing: All benchmarks run with --offline flag to avoid network interference
 Integration Testing: End-to-end functionality verified

💡 Benefits
Developer Experience

Type Safety: Compile-time validation prevents common string identifier errors
IDE Support: Better autocomplete, navigation, and refactoring capabilities
Debugging: Clear type information makes issues easier to identify and fix
Maintainability: Self-documenting code with explicit type contracts

Runtime Benefits

Error Prevention: Branded types catch identifier mix-ups before they cause issues
Data Integrity: Ensured format consistency across the application
Performance Balance: Optimizations where they matter most (hot paths)

Future-Proofing

Extensibility: Easy to add new branded types for additional domain concepts
Migration Path: Smooth upgrade path for existing data and usage patterns
Type Evolution: Foundation for more advanced type safety features

🔄 Migration Notes
This change is backward compatible - no user action required:

Existing JSONL data continues to work unchanged
All CLI commands maintain identical behavior
API contracts preserved for programmatic usage
Performance characteristics remain within acceptable bounds


Trade-off Summary: ~3% performance cost for significant type safety improvements - excellent value proposition for a development tool prioritizing reliability and maintainability.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced enhanced validation and type safety for key data fields, including dates, identifiers, and model names.
Added helper functions for safely creating and validating these branded data types.



Refactor

Merge pull request #108 from ryoppippi/uniq

Refactor: replace Set with es-toolkit uniq for better code readability

nodes.title: Refactor: replace Set with es-toolkit uniq for better code readability
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Replace JavaScript Set usage with es-toolkit uniq function for better code readability and consistency throughout the codebase.
Changes Made

utils.internal.ts: Replace [...new Set(models.map(formatModelName))] with uniq(models.map(formatModelName))
session-blocks.internal.ts: Replace Set-based model collection with array + uniq()
data-loader.ts: Replace Set usage in three locations:

extractUniqueModels function
Session data version collection
Monthly data model collection



Key Benefits

Improved readability: uniq() is more explicit about the intent than Set construction
Consistency: Aligns with existing es-toolkit usage patterns in the codebase
Simpler code: Eliminates need for Array.from() conversions
Maintained functionality: All unique collection behavior preserved

What Was Preserved
Set instances used for deduplication checking (via has()/add() methods) were intentionally kept unchanged as they serve a different purpose than unique collection.
Test Plan

 All existing tests pass (182/182)
 TypeScript compilation succeeds
 ESLint formatting applied
 Functionality verified through test suite


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Improved internal logic for extracting unique values by utilizing a standardized utility function, ensuring consistent and reliable uniqueness filtering across various features. No changes to visible features or user-facing functionality.

nodes.message:
refactor: replace Set with es-toolkit uniq in data-loader.ts

Replace multiple Set-based unique collection patterns with es-toolkit uniq function
for improved readability and consistency. This affects three main areas:

1. extractUniqueModels function: Replace [...new Set(...)] with uniq(...)
2. Session data version collection: Replace Set with array + uniq()
3. Monthly data model collection: Replace Set with array + uniq()

All Set instances used for deduplication via has()/add() methods are preserved
as they serve a different purpose (duplicate detection vs unique collection).

The changes maintain identical functionality while improving code clarity
and establishing consistent use of es-toolkit utilities.

nodes.title: docs: add MCP Inspector testing documentation
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Add comprehensive MCP Inspector testing documentation to improve developer experience with MCP server functionality.
Changes

📚 Documentation Enhancement: Added new "Testing MCP Server" section to README.md
🔧 npm Script Addition: Added `mcp` script to package.json for easy MCP Inspector testing
🛠️ Developer Tools: Document both interactive web UI and direct command-line testing approaches

Key Features Added
The new documentation covers:

Interactive Testing: `bun run mcp` command for web-based MCP Inspector interface
Direct Testing: Alternative `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector ccusage mcp` command
Feature Overview: Clear list of MCP Inspector capabilities including:

Individual MCP tool testing (daily, monthly, session, blocks)
Tool schema and parameter inspection
Server response debugging
Configuration export functionality



Benefits

Improved Discoverability: Makes MCP server testing more accessible to developers
Enhanced Developer Experience: Provides clear instructions for debugging and validation
Better Documentation: Comprehensive coverage of available testing approaches
Streamlined Workflow: Simple npm script for quick testing access

Test Plan

 Verify `bun run mcp` command works correctly
 Confirm MCP Inspector web interface launches successfully
 Test direct npx command execution
 Validate documentation accuracy and completeness
 Ensure formatting and linting passes

This change makes MCP server development and testing more approachable while maintaining the existing functionality.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added instructions for testing the MCP server using the MCP Inspector tool, including example commands and feature descriptions.


Chores

Introduced a new npm script to simplify running the MCP Inspector for server testing.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #106 from ryoppippi/test-refactor

test: improve MCP server test coverage with comprehensive normal and error cases

nodes.title: test: improve MCP server test coverage with comprehensive normal and error cases
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Add comprehensive HTTP transport tests with actual MCP protocol requests
Add error handling tests for invalid arguments, dates, and unknown tools
Add edge case tests for empty directories, malformed files, and missing paths
Add concurrent tool call testing for thread safety validation

Background
The MCP server tests were missing coverage for:

Normal HTTP transport operations - Only had basic app creation test
Error handling scenarios - No tests for invalid inputs or error responses
Edge cases - No tests for empty data, malformed files, or concurrent access

Changes Made
1. HTTP Transport Testing

MCP initialize request test - Tests proper SSE response format and JSON-RPC protocol compliance
MCP tool call test - Tests daily tool execution via HTTP with proper response validation
Response format validation - Extracts and validates JSON data from Server-Sent Events responses

2. Error Handling Tests

Invalid arguments test - Tests tool calls with invalid enum values (mode: "invalid_mode")
Invalid date format test - Tests date parameter validation (YYYYMMDD format)
Unknown tool test - Tests error response for non-existent tool names
Uses proper toThrow() exception testing for MCP protocol errors

3. Edge Case Tests

Empty data directory - Tests graceful handling when no usage data exists
Malformed JSONL files - Tests silent skipping of invalid JSON lines
Missing Claude directory - Tests behavior with non-existent data paths
Concurrent tool calls - Tests thread safety with parallel tool execution

Test Results

Before: 11 MCP tests (mainly happy path scenarios)
After: 18 MCP tests (comprehensive coverage)
Total project tests: 182 passing
All tests validated against current Claude 4 models

Technical Details
Protocol Compliance

Tests validate proper JSON-RPC 2.0 format in responses
SSE (Server-Sent Events) format properly parsed and validated
Protocol version and capabilities correctly tested

Error Response Format

MCP SDK throws McpError exceptions for invalid inputs
Tests use expect().rejects.toThrow() for proper exception validation
Error messages include detailed validation information

Edge Case Robustness

Empty data scenarios return valid empty arrays
Malformed files are silently skipped (existing behavior preserved)
Missing directories handled gracefully without crashes
Concurrent access tested for all 4 tools (daily, session, monthly, blocks)

Test Coverage Impact
This PR significantly improves the reliability and robustness testing of the MCP server implementation, ensuring it handles both normal operations and error conditions correctly according to the MCP protocol specification.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Tests

Added extensive new test cases covering HTTP transport and protocol handling, including initialization, tool calls, error scenarios, edge cases, and concurrent requests to ensure robust server behavior.

- Add error handling tests for invalid arguments, dates, and unknown tools
- Add edge case tests for empty directories, malformed files, and concurrent access
- Use dynamic package version in assertions for better maintainability
- Increase test count from 11 to 18 with full protocol compliance validation

nodes.title: feat: add comprehensive MCP server tests
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds comprehensive test coverage for the MCP (Model Context Protocol) server functionality, covering both stdio and HTTP transport modes.
⚠️ BREAKING CHANGES
🚨 Migration from valibot to zod: Schema validation now uses zod instead of valibot for better type safety and ecosystem compatibility
🚨 Migration from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk + Hono by @yusukebe:

Replaced fastmcp with official MCP SDK for better compatibility and future-proofing
HTTP transport now uses Hono framework by @yusukebe for improved performance and developer experience
This provides more robust MCP protocol support and better HTTP handling

Changes Made

In-Source Testing: Added tests using the if (import.meta.vitest != null) pattern directly in src/mcp.ts
Stdio Transport Tests: Test server creation, tool listing, and individual tool calls with mock Claude data
HTTP Transport Tests: Test Hono app creation, HTTP request handling, and error responses
Mock Data: Use fs-fixture with createFixture() to simulate Claude data directory structure
Documentation: Updated CLAUDE.md with in-source testing guidelines and patterns

Test Coverage

MCP server creation with default/custom options
Stdio transport connection and tool listing (4 tools: daily, session, monthly, blocks)
All MCP tools execute successfully and return valid JSON data
HTTP transport handles valid POST requests and returns proper error codes
Error handling for malformed JSON and invalid HTTP methods

Testing Pattern
This follows the project in-source testing pattern with vitest globals and fs-fixture for mocking.
The tests ensure the MCP server works correctly for external integrations.

nodes.message:

nodes.title: feat: add comprehensive MCP server tests
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds comprehensive test coverage for the MCP (Model Context Protocol) server functionality, covering both stdio and HTTP transport modes.
⚠️ BREAKING CHANGES
🚨 Migration from valibot to zod: Schema validation now uses zod instead of valibot for better type safety and ecosystem compatibility
🚨 Migration from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk + Hono by @yusukebe:

Replaced fastmcp with official MCP SDK for better compatibility and future-proofing
HTTP transport now uses Hono framework by @yusukebe for improved performance and developer experience
This provides more robust MCP protocol support and better HTTP handling

Changes Made

In-Source Testing: Added tests using the if (import.meta.vitest != null) pattern directly in src/mcp.ts
Stdio Transport Tests: Test server creation, tool listing, and individual tool calls with mock Claude data
HTTP Transport Tests: Test Hono app creation, HTTP request handling, and error responses
Mock Data: Use fs-fixture with createFixture() to simulate Claude data directory structure
Documentation: Updated CLAUDE.md with in-source testing guidelines and patterns

Test Coverage

MCP server creation with default/custom options
Stdio transport connection and tool listing (4 tools: daily, session, monthly, blocks)
All MCP tools execute successfully and return valid JSON data
HTTP transport handles valid POST requests and returns proper error codes
Error handling for malformed JSON and invalid HTTP methods

Testing Pattern
This follows the project in-source testing pattern with vitest globals and fs-fixture for mocking.
The tests ensure the MCP server works correctly for external integrations.

nodes.message:
feat: add comprehensive MCP server tests for stdio and HTTP transports

- Add in-source tests for MCP server functionality using vitest pattern
- Test stdio transport with InMemoryTransport for client-server communication
- Test HTTP transport with Hono app request/response handling
- Validate all 4 MCP tools (daily, session, monthly, blocks) work correctly
- Mock Claude data directory using fs-fixture for isolated testing
- Test error handling for invalid JSON, method not allowed scenarios
- Update CLAUDE.md with in-source testing guidelines and patterns

The tests ensure MCP server works correctly in both stdio and HTTP modes,
providing comprehensive coverage for external integrations.

Merge pull request #99 from ryoppippi/zod

refactor: migrate to zod and official MCP SDK with HTTP transport support

nodes.title: refactor: migrate to zod and official MCP SDK with HTTP transport support
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR completes a major dependency migration and architecture modernization with significant bundle size improvements:
• Validation Library Migration: Replace valibot with zod for all schema validation, improving type safety and ecosystem compatibility
• MCP SDK Upgrade: Migrate from fastmcp to the official @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for better standards compliance
• HTTP Transport Support: Add HTTP transport capability to the MCP server using Hono framework, enabling web-based integrations
• Bundle Size Optimization: Reduced total bundle size by 47% (2184.77 kB → 1161.68 kB)
• Code Quality Improvements: Enhanced documentation, simplified validation logic, and modernized null handling
Performance Improvements
Bundle Size Reduction:

Before: ℹ 34 files, total: 2184.77 kB
After: ℹ 23 files, total: 1161.68 kB
Improvement: -1023.09 kB (-47% reduction)

This significant size reduction improves:

Faster installation and startup times
Reduced memory footprint
Better performance on resource-constrained environments

Changes Made
Core Dependencies:

Replaced valibot with zod for schema validation throughout the codebase
Migrated from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for official MCP protocol support
Added hono and @hono/node-server for HTTP transport functionality

Schema Migration:

Updated all validation schemas in data-loader.ts, types.ts, and command files
Maintained backward compatibility with existing data structures
Improved type inference and runtime validation

MCP Server Enhancements:

Added HTTP transport support alongside existing stdio transport
Implemented flexible transport selection via CLI flags
Enhanced server configuration and error handling

Code Quality Improvements:

Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation to key MCP functions
Removed redundant argument validation in MCP tools (MCP SDK handles validation)
Simplified error handling with explicit fallback messages
Replaced ternary null checks with nullish coalescing operator (??) for cleaner code

Benefits

Better Type Safety: Zod provides superior TypeScript integration and runtime validation
Official MCP Support: Using the official SDK ensures better compatibility and future support
Enhanced Flexibility: HTTP transport enables new integration possibilities
Improved Performance: 47% bundle size reduction improves startup and memory usage
Better Developer Experience: Better error messages, improved documentation, and cleaner code
Reduced Code Complexity: Eliminated redundant validation and simplified conditional logic

AI Review Feedback Addressed
This PR incorporates feedback from multiple AI code reviewers:

CodeRabbit: Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation
Gemini Code Assist: Removed redundant argument validation in MCP server tools
Copilot: Improved error handling with fallback messages and simplified mode conversion
Additional improvements: Modernized null handling with nullish coalescing operator

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for running the server over both HTTP and standard input/output transports.
Introduced new HTTP server utilities for usage reporting.



Refactor

Replaced the schema validation library with Zod for improved data validation and consistency.
Modernized server implementation and tool registration for usage reports.
Updated command handling and server startup logic for clearer transport separation.



Chores

Updated development dependencies, replacing and removing several packages.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

nodes.message:
refactor: replace ternary null checks with nullish coalescing operator

Replace explicit null checks with ?? operator for cleaner, more idiomatic code:

- src/commands/blocks.ts: actualEndTime null check simplified
- src/session-blocks.internal.ts: costUSD null check simplified

These changes improve readability while maintaining identical functionality.
The ?? operator is more concise and clearly expresses the intent of
providing fallback values for null/undefined cases.

docs: add comprehensive JSDoc documentation to MCP server functions

Following CodeRabbit PR review suggestions, this commit adds detailed JSDoc
documentation to key MCP server functions to improve code maintainability
and developer experience:

- createMcpServer: Added parameter documentation and return type description
- validateArgs: Internal function for argument validation with proper typing
- startMcpServerStdio: Clarified stdio transport usage and purpose
- createMcpHttpApp: Detailed HTTP transport functionality and Hono integration
- mcpCommand: Enhanced command description and purpose documentation

The documentation includes:
* Function purpose and behavior
* Parameter descriptions with types
* Return value explanations
* Usage context for transport methods

These improvements address the finishing touches suggested in PR #99
review comments and enhance the codebase documentation standards.

nodes.message:
refactor(mcp): migrate from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk

- Replace FastMCP import with McpServer from @modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/mcp.js
- Update server initialization to use new McpServer API
- Replace server.addTool() with server.registerTool() API
  - Update tool registration to use object configuration with description and inputSchema
  - Change return format to include content array with type and text properties
- Convert valibot schema definitions to zod equivalents
  - Remove JSON Schema format, use zod schema objects directly
  - inputSchema now accepts zod shape objects instead of JSON Schema
- Update commands/mcp.ts to use StdioServerTransport
  - Remove HTTP transport support (not directly supported by new SDK)
  - Update server connection to use transport.connect() pattern
- Add ESLint disable for ts/no-unsafe-assignment in validateArgs function

The MCP server maintains the same functionality with daily, session, monthly, and blocks tools.

nodes.title: refactor: migrate to zod and official MCP SDK with HTTP transport support
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR completes a major dependency migration and architecture modernization with significant bundle size improvements:
• Validation Library Migration: Replace valibot with zod for all schema validation, improving type safety and ecosystem compatibility
• MCP SDK Upgrade: Migrate from fastmcp to the official @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for better standards compliance
• HTTP Transport Support: Add HTTP transport capability to the MCP server using Hono framework, enabling web-based integrations
• Bundle Size Optimization: Reduced total bundle size by 47% (2184.77 kB → 1161.68 kB)
• Code Quality Improvements: Enhanced documentation, simplified validation logic, and modernized null handling
Performance Improvements
Bundle Size Reduction:

Before: ℹ 34 files, total: 2184.77 kB
After: ℹ 23 files, total: 1161.68 kB
Improvement: -1023.09 kB (-47% reduction)

This significant size reduction improves:

Faster installation and startup times
Reduced memory footprint
Better performance on resource-constrained environments

Changes Made
Core Dependencies:

Replaced valibot with zod for schema validation throughout the codebase
Migrated from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for official MCP protocol support
Added hono and @hono/node-server for HTTP transport functionality

Schema Migration:

Updated all validation schemas in data-loader.ts, types.ts, and command files
Maintained backward compatibility with existing data structures
Improved type inference and runtime validation

MCP Server Enhancements:

Added HTTP transport support alongside existing stdio transport
Implemented flexible transport selection via CLI flags
Enhanced server configuration and error handling

Code Quality Improvements:

Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation to key MCP functions
Removed redundant argument validation in MCP tools (MCP SDK handles validation)
Simplified error handling with explicit fallback messages
Replaced ternary null checks with nullish coalescing operator (??) for cleaner code

Benefits

Better Type Safety: Zod provides superior TypeScript integration and runtime validation
Official MCP Support: Using the official SDK ensures better compatibility and future support
Enhanced Flexibility: HTTP transport enables new integration possibilities
Improved Performance: 47% bundle size reduction improves startup and memory usage
Better Developer Experience: Better error messages, improved documentation, and cleaner code
Reduced Code Complexity: Eliminated redundant validation and simplified conditional logic

AI Review Feedback Addressed
This PR incorporates feedback from multiple AI code reviewers:

CodeRabbit: Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation
Gemini Code Assist: Removed redundant argument validation in MCP server tools
Copilot: Improved error handling with fallback messages and simplified mode conversion
Additional improvements: Modernized null handling with nullish coalescing operator

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for running the server over both HTTP and standard input/output transports.
Introduced new HTTP server utilities for usage reporting.



Refactor

Replaced the schema validation library with Zod for improved data validation and consistency.
Modernized server implementation and tool registration for usage reports.
Updated command handling and server startup logic for clearer transport separation.



Chores

Updated development dependencies, replacing and removing several packages.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

nodes.message:
refactor(types): migrate type schemas from valibot to zod

- Replace valibot imports with zod imports
- Convert dateSchema from valibot pipe syntax to zod method chaining
  - v.pipe(v.string(), v.regex()) → z.string().regex()
- Convert modelPricingSchema from valibot to zod
  - v.optional(v.number()) → z.number().optional()
  - v.object() → z.object()
- Update type definitions to use zod inference
  - v.InferOutput → z.infer
- Maintain identical validation logic and type structure

style: standardize schema naming conventions

nodes.title: style: standardize schema naming conventions
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Standardize Valibot schema variable names to follow camelCase convention (variables start with lowercase)
Rename all schema variables from PascalCase to camelCase while keeping type names unchanged
Add naming conventions documentation to CLAUDE.md
Fix test command documentation in CLAUDE.md

Changes Made
Schema Renames (6 commits, one per schema):


UsageDataSchema → usageDataSchema

Main schema for Claude usage data from JSONL files
Updated in data-loader.ts and debug.ts



ModelBreakdownSchema → modelBreakdownSchema

Schema for model-specific usage breakdown data
Updated all array references in other schemas



DailyUsageSchema → dailyUsageSchema

Schema for daily usage aggregation data



SessionUsageSchema → sessionUsageSchema

Schema for session-based usage aggregation data



MonthlyUsageSchema → monthlyUsageSchema

Schema for monthly usage aggregation data



ModelPricingSchema → modelPricingSchema

Schema for model pricing information from LiteLLM
Updated in types.internal.ts, macro.internal.ts, and pricing-fetcher.ts



Documentation Updates:

Added naming conventions to CLAUDE.md:

Variables: camelCase (e.g., usageDataSchema, modelBreakdownSchema)
Types: PascalCase (e.g., UsageData, ModelBreakdown)
Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH)


Fixed test command documentation to use "bun run test"

Test Results
✅ All 164 tests pass
✅ TypeScript compilation successful
✅ ESLint formatting applied
Naming Convention Rationale
This change follows standard JavaScript/TypeScript conventions:

Variables (including schema definitions): start with lowercase letter
Types/Interfaces: start with uppercase letter
Constants: can use UPPER_SNAKE_CASE

The schemas are Valibot schema objects assigned to const variables, so they should follow variable naming conventions (camelCase), while the inferred types from these schemas correctly follow type naming conventions (PascalCase).

nodes.message:
docs: fix test command in CLAUDE.md

- Update test command reference to use "bun run test" instead of just "bun test"
- Clarify that vitest runs via bun in the description
- Fix command in post-code change workflow section

This ensures the correct command is documented for running tests.

Updated in types.internal.ts, macro.internal.ts, and pricing-fetcher.ts



Documentation Updates:

Added naming conventions to CLAUDE.md:

Variables: camelCase (e.g., usageDataSchema, modelBreakdownSchema)
Types: PascalCase (e.g., UsageData, ModelBreakdown)
Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH)


Fixed test command documentation to use "bun run test"

Test Results
✅ All 164 tests pass
✅ TypeScript compilation successful
✅ ESLint formatting applied
Naming Convention Rationale
This change follows standard JavaScript/TypeScript conventions:

Variables (including schema definitions): start with lowercase letter
Types/Interfaces: start with uppercase letter
Constants: can use UPPER_SNAKE_CASE

The schemas are Valibot schema objects assigned to const variables, so they should follow variable naming conventions (camelCase), while the inferred types from these schemas correctly follow type naming conventions (PascalCase).

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #94 from ryoppippi/ryoppippi/vitest

feat: migrate test framework from bun:test to vitest

nodes.title: feat: migrate test framework from bun:test to vitest
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
We migrate from bun:test to  vitest.
We really like the speed of bun:test but they haven't implemented stubEnv yet.
So for now we'll use vitest
Key Changes

Dependencies: Added vitest@^3.2.4 and @vitest/ui@^3.2.4, removed @types/bun
Configuration: Created vitest.config.ts with globals enabled for seamless testing
Test Scripts: Updated package.json scripts to use vitest run instead of bun test
Environment Variables: Enhanced testing with vitest's vi.stubEnv() and vi.unstubAllEnvs() for cleaner mocking
Documentation: Updated CLAUDE.md and README.md to reflect new testing commands

Features Enhanced

Better Environment Variable Testing: Replaced manual environment variable manipulation with vitest's built-in stubbing
Global Test Functions: Configured vitest globals for cleaner test imports
TypeScript Integration: Properly configured TypeScript types for vitest globals

Technical Details

All 164 tests pass successfully with vitest
Environment variable testing improved in data-loader.test.ts using vi.stubEnv()
Maintained backward compatibility with existing test patterns
Added comprehensive vitest configuration with node environment
Updated TypeScript configuration to include vitest globals

Test Coverage

✅ 7 test files migrated
✅ 164 tests passing
✅ All environment variable mocking enhanced
✅ TypeScript types properly configured
✅ Lint and format checks passing

Commits

feat: add vitest dependencies and update test scripts
feat: add vitest configuration
feat: configure vitest globals and migrate core test imports
refactor: migrate remaining test imports to vitest globals
enhance: improve environment variable testing with vitest features
docs: update CLAUDE.md to use bun run test for vitest
docs: update README.md development command

Test Plan

 Run all tests with bun run test (vitest)
 Verify TypeScript compilation with bun typecheck
 Validate code formatting with bun run format
 Confirm environment variable stubbing works correctly
 Verify all 164 tests pass without regression


Summary by CodeRabbit


Documentation

Updated instructions for running tests and development scripts to reflect new command usage.
Clarified testing and development setup in documentation files.



Chores

Switched the testing framework from Bun's built-in runner to Vitest.
Updated scripts and dependencies to support Vitest, including UI support.
Added a Vitest configuration file and adjusted TypeScript settings for Vitest compatibility.



Tests

Migrated test files to use Vitest syntax and utilities.
Improved environment variable handling in tests.
Added new tests for session duration configuration.

Configuration: Created vitest.config.ts with globals enabled for seamless testing
Test Scripts: Updated package.json scripts to use vitest run instead of bun test
Environment Variables: Enhanced testing with vitest's vi.stubEnv() and vi.unstubAllEnvs() for cleaner mocking
Documentation: Updated CLAUDE.md and README.md to reflect new testing commands

Features Enhanced

Better Environment Variable Testing: Replaced manual environment variable manipulation with vitest's built-in stubbing
Global Test Functions: Configured vitest globals for cleaner test imports
TypeScript Integration: Properly configured TypeScript types for vitest globals

Technical Details

All 164 tests pass successfully with vitest
Environment variable testing improved in data-loader.test.ts using vi.stubEnv()
Maintained backward compatibility with existing test patterns
Added comprehensive vitest configuration with node environment
Updated TypeScript configuration to include vitest globals

Test Coverage

✅ 7 test files migrated
✅ 164 tests passing
✅ All environment variable mocking enhanced
✅ TypeScript types properly configured
✅ Lint and format checks passing

Commits

feat: add vitest dependencies and update test scripts
feat: add vitest configuration
feat: configure vitest globals and migrate core test imports
refactor: migrate remaining test imports to vitest globals
enhance: improve environment variable testing with vitest features
docs: update CLAUDE.md to use bun run test for vitest
docs: update README.md development command

Test Plan

 Run all tests with bun run test (vitest)
 Verify TypeScript compilation with bun typecheck
 Validate code formatting with bun run format
 Confirm environment variable stubbing works correctly
 Verify all 164 tests pass without regression


Summary by CodeRabbit


Documentation

Updated instructions for running tests and development scripts to reflect new command usage.
Clarified testing and development setup in documentation files.



Chores

Switched the testing framework from Bun's built-in runner to Vitest.
Updated scripts and dependencies to support Vitest, including UI support.
Added a Vitest configuration file and adjusted TypeScript settings for Vitest compatibility.



Tests

Migrated test files to use Vitest syntax and utilities.
Improved environment variable handling in tests.
Added new tests for session duration configuration.

nodes.title: chore(deps): update dependency lint-staged to ^16.1.1
nodes.bodyText:
This PR contains the following updates:



Package
Change
Age
Adoption
Passing
Confidence




lint-staged
^16.1.0 -> ^16.1.1








Release Notes

lint-staged/lint-staged (lint-staged)
v16.1.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#​1565 3686977 Thanks @​iiroj! - Lint-staged now explicitly warns about potential data loss when using --no-stash.


#​1571 02299a9 Thanks @​iiroj! - Function tasks (introduced in v16.0.0) only received the staged files matching the conpmnfigured glob, instead of all staged files.


#​1563 bc61c74 Thanks @​iiroj! - This version fixes incorrect behavior where unstaged changes were committed when using the --no-stash option. This happened because --no-stash implied --no-hide-partially-staged, meaning unstaged changes to files which also had other staged changes were added to the commit by lint-staged; this is no longer the case.
The previous (incorrect) behavior can still be achieved by using both options --no-stash --no-hide-partially-staged at the same time.




Configuration
📅 Schedule: Branch creation - At any time (no schedule defined), Automerge - At any time (no schedule defined).
🚦 Automerge: Enabled.
♻ Rebasing: Whenever PR is behind base branch, or you tick the rebase/retry checkbox.
🔕 Ignore: Close this PR and you won't be reminded about this update again.

docs: add comprehensive JSDoc documentation for all functions and types

nodes.title: docs: add comprehensive JSDoc documentation for all functions and types
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds comprehensive JSDoc documentation throughout the codebase to improve developer experience and code maintainability.
Changes Made

Type Definitions & Constants: Added JSDoc for shared types, CLI arguments, and configuration constants
Core Utilities: Documented logger, cost calculation, and formatting functions
Data Processing: Added documentation for data loading, aggregation, and validation schemas
Pricing System: Comprehensive documentation for LiteLLM integration and cost calculations
Session Blocks: Detailed docs for billing period analysis and usage projections
Debug Tools: Documentation for pricing mismatch detection and reporting
CLI Commands: Added docs for command infrastructure and user interface components

Test Plan

 All existing tests pass
 TypeScript compilation succeeds
 ESLint formatting applied
 JSDoc comments follow consistent style
 Function parameters and return types documented
 Complex algorithms explained with clear descriptions

Benefits

Easier onboarding for new contributors
Better IDE intellisense and autocomplete
Clear understanding of function purposes and parameters
Improved code maintainability
Consistent documentation style across the codebase


Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added comprehensive inline documentation throughout the codebase, including detailed descriptions for constants, types, classes, and functions.
Improved clarity on parameters, return values, and usage of various exported entities.
Enhanced code readability and maintainability with JSDoc-style comments.
No changes to application behavior or functionality.

nodes.message:
Merge pull request #92 from ryoppippi/session-length

feat: add configurable session length to blocks command

nodes.title: feat: add configurable session length to blocks command
nodes.bodyText:
Summary

Added --session-length (-l) option to customize session block duration in hours
Default remains 5 hours for backward compatibility
Supports any positive number of hours (including decimals like 2.5)
Added validation to ensure session length is positive
Comprehensive test coverage for various duration scenarios

Changes Made
Core Implementation

session-blocks.internal.ts: Made session duration configurable by updating identifySessionBlocks() to accept optional sessionDurationHours parameter
data-loader.ts: Added sessionDurationHours to LoadOptions and passed through to session block identification
blocks.ts: Added CLI option with validation and help text

Testing

Added 9 comprehensive tests covering custom durations (1h, 2h, 2.5h, 3h, 24h, 0.5h)
Tests verify correct block creation, gap detection, and timing
Edge cases covered: fractional hours, exactly equal durations, backward compatibility

Validation

Input validation ensures positive session lengths
All existing functionality preserved (164 tests pass)
Code formatted and type-checked

Usage Examples
Default 5-hour sessions (backward compatible):
bun run start blocks
Custom 3-hour sessions:
bun run start blocks --session-length 3
Short 1-hour sessions for fine-grained tracking:
bun run start blocks -l 1
Fractional hours:
bun run start blocks --session-length 2.5
Works with all existing options:
bun run start blocks --session-length 8 --recent --json
Test Plan

✅ Run bun test - all 164 tests pass
✅ Test blocks command with default duration
✅ Test with custom duration and fractional hours
✅ Verify gap detection works with custom durations
✅ Test edge cases (very small/large durations)
✅ Run linting and type checking
✅ Test validation with invalid values
✅ Verify JSON output includes correct timing
✅ Test table display shows correct durations

Implementation Notes
The feature correctly handles:

Gap Detection: Gaps created only when time between entries exceeds custom session duration
Block Timing: End times are exactly sessionDurationHours after start times
Active Blocks: Properly calculates remaining time based on custom duration
JSON Output: Includes correct timing information in API responses
Table Display: Shows correct durations and remaining time in CLI tables

Full backward compatibility maintained while providing flexibility for different use cases.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Added a command-line option to customize the session block duration in hours.


Bug Fixes

Improved validation for session duration input to ensure only positive values are accepted.


Tests

Introduced comprehensive tests to verify correct grouping of session blocks with various session durations.


Documentation

Updated descriptions and help text to reflect the new configurable session duration option.

nodes.message:
test: add comprehensive tests for configurable session duration

- Test custom session durations (1h, 2h, 2.5h, 3h, 24h, 0.5h)
- Test gap block creation with custom durations
- Test edge cases (exactly equal durations, fractional hours)
- Test backward compatibility (default 5h behavior)
- All tests verify correct block creation, gap detection, and timing

Covers various scenarios to ensure robust session block identification
with configurable durations across different time ranges.

bun run start blocks
Custom 3-hour sessions:
bun run start blocks --session-length 3
Short 1-hour sessions for fine-grained tracking:
bun run start blocks -l 1
Fractional hours:
bun run start blocks --session-length 2.5
Works with all existing options:
bun run start blocks --session-length 8 --recent --json
Test Plan

✅ Run bun test - all 164 tests pass
✅ Test blocks command with default duration
✅ Test with custom duration and fractional hours
✅ Verify gap detection works with custom durations
✅ Test edge cases (very small/large durations)
✅ Run linting and type checking
✅ Test validation with invalid values
✅ Verify JSON output includes correct timing
✅ Test table display shows correct durations

Implementation Notes
The feature correctly handles:

Gap Detection: Gaps created only when time between entries exceeds custom session duration
Block Timing: End times are exactly sessionDurationHours after start times
Active Blocks: Properly calculates remaining time based on custom duration
JSON Output: Includes correct timing information in API responses
Table Display: Shows correct durations and remaining time in CLI tables

Full backward compatibility maintained while providing flexibility for different use cases.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Added a command-line option to customize the session block duration in hours.


Bug Fixes

Improved validation for session duration input to ensure only positive values are accepted.


Tests

Introduced comprehensive tests to verify correct grouping of session blocks with various session durations.


Documentation

Updated descriptions and help text to reflect the new configurable session duration option.

refactor: rename five-hour terminology to session terminology

nodes.title: refactor: rename five-hour terminology to session terminology
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors the codebase to use session terminology instead of five-hour terminology, aligning with Claude Code official billing session concept. Based on Anthropic documentation, Claude Code uses 5-hour sessions for billing, so the code should reflect this semantic meaning rather than just describing the duration.
Changes Made

Constants: FIVE_HOURS_MS → SESSION_DURATION_MS
Types: FiveHourBlock → SessionBlock
Functions: identifyFiveHourBlocks → identifySessionBlocks, loadFiveHourBlockData → loadSessionBlockData
Files: five-hour-blocks.internal.ts → session-blocks.internal.ts
User-facing text: Updated command descriptions, error messages, and UI labels
Tests: Updated all test files to use new terminology

Why This Change?
After researching Claude Code billing documentation, I found that the 5-hour period represents Claude official session billing cycle. Users start a session with their first message, and it lasts for 5 hours. The term session is more semantically accurate than five-hour blocks and aligns with Anthropic official terminology.
Impact

✅ All tests pass
✅ TypeScript compilation successful
✅ ESLint formatting applied
✅ No breaking changes to functionality
✅ Only terminology and naming updated
✅ Documentation reflects accurate Claude Code billing concepts

Test Plan

 Run bun test - all 155 tests pass
 Run bun typecheck - no TypeScript errors
 Run bun run format - code properly formatted
 Verify functionality unchanged - session block logic works identically
 Check user-facing text updated consistently across CLI and MCP server


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Updated all terminology and functionality from "five-hour blocks" to "session blocks" across the app, including commands, descriptions, logs, and data structures.
Renamed relevant constants, types, and functions to reflect the new "session block" terminology.


Tests

Updated all tests to use "session blocks" instead of "five-hour blocks," ensuring scenarios and expectations remain consistent.

nodes.message:
fix: update test files to use session terminology

Update all test files to use new session terminology:
- FIVE_HOURS_MS → SESSION_DURATION_MS
- FiveHourBlock → SessionBlock
- loadFiveHourBlockData → loadSessionBlockData
- identifyFiveHourBlocks → identifySessionBlocks

This fixes compilation errors after refactoring to session-based naming
convention. All test logic remains the same, only terminology has been
updated to match the new API.

reflect Claude Code official billing session terminology. This aligns with
Anthropic documented 5-hour session billing cycles and makes the code more
semantically clear about what the time period represents.

The constant value remains unchanged (5 * 60 * 60 * 1000 = 18000000ms) but
the name now accurately describes it as a session duration rather than just
five hours.

feat(mcp): add monthly and blocks tools to MCP server

nodes.title: feat(mcp): add monthly and blocks tools to MCP server
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
• Add monthly usage report tool to MCP server
• Add 5-hour billing blocks usage report tool to MCP server
• Update documentation for new MCP tools and blocks command
MCP Server Enhancements
New Tools Added:

`monthly` - Returns monthly usage reports with same parameters as existing tools
`blocks` - Returns 5-hour billing blocks usage reports with billing cycle tracking

API Consistency:

Both tools accept standard parameters: `since`, `until`, `mode`
JSON output format consistent with existing `daily` and `session` tools
Seamless integration with existing MCP client implementations

Documentation Updates
CLAUDE.md:

Added comprehensive blocks command usage examples
Updated MCP integration section with all 4 available tools
Enhanced development commands with MCP server options
Updated data structures documentation for 5-hour billing blocks

README.md:

Added 5-Hour Blocks Report feature documentation
Added MCP Integration feature highlighting
Updated MCP tools list with complete tool descriptions
Maintained consistency with existing documentation patterns

Test Plan

 Verify monthly tool returns valid JSON with monthly aggregated data
 Verify blocks tool returns valid JSON with 5-hour block data
 Confirm MCP server starts successfully with new tools
 Validate parameter passing works correctly for new tools
 Check documentation accuracy and completeness
 Ensure consistent API interface across all MCP tools
 All tests pass
 Lint and typecheck pass


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced 5-hour billing blocks reporting, enabling detailed tracking of usage within billing windows.
Added monthly and 5-hour block usage reports to the MCP server, with options for filtering and cost calculation.
Enhanced MCP integration, including built-in server support for new reporting tools.



Documentation

Updated documentation and README to reflect new 5-hour billing block and monthly reporting features, as well as expanded MCP integration details.

- blocks: Returns 5-hour billing blocks usage reports

Both tools accept the same parameters as existing tools

to enable block-based usage data retrieval through the MCP protocol.

The blocks tool provides usage reports grouped by Claude's
5-hour billing blocks, useful for understanding usage patterns
within billing cycles and active block monitoring.

nodes.title: feat: add 5-hour blocks report command
nodes.bodyText:
Summary
This PR implements a new blocks command to analyze Claude Code usage in 5-hour billing windows as requested in #23.
Features

5-Hour Block Tracking: Groups usage into Claude's 5-hour session windows that start with first message
Active Block Monitoring: Shows time elapsed/remaining and burn rate for current sessions
Token Limit Support: Set limits with -t <number> or use -t max to automatically use highest previous block
Usage Projections: Projects total usage if current burn rate continues for the full 5 hours
Recent Filter: --recent flag shows only last 3 days of blocks
Detailed Active View: --active flag shows detailed view of current active block

Implementation Details

Core logic in src/utils/five-hour-blocks.ts handles block detection and calculations
New CLI command in src/commands/blocks.ts with table and JSON output formats
Integrated with existing data loader infrastructure
Added comprehensive documentation to README

Example Output
┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┬─────────────┬─────────────────────────┬────────┬────────┬─────────┐
│ Block Start                                            │ Duration/   │ Models                  │ Tokens │ %      │ Cost    │
│                                                        │ Status      │                         │        │        │         │
├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────┼─────────────────────────┼────────┼────────┼─────────┤
│ 6/16/2025, 6:21:16 PM (1h 25m elapsed, 3h 35m remain) │ ACTIVE      │ claude-opus-4-20250514  │ 25,979 │ 41.8%  │ $74.54  │
├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────┼─────────────────────────┼────────┼────────┼─────────┤
│                      (assuming 62,081 token limit)    │ REMAINING   │                         │ 36,102 │ 58.2%  │         │
├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────┼─────────────────────────┼────────┼────────┼─────────┤
│                       (assuming current burn rate)    │ PROJECTED   │                         │ 91,443 │ 147.3% │ $262.09 │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┴─────────────┴─────────────────────────┴────────┴────────┴─────────┘

Testing

All existing tests pass
TypeScript compilation successful
Manual testing with various scenarios including active blocks, token limits, and edge cases

Fixes #23
🤖 Generated with Claude Code
Co-Authored-By: @a-c-m

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Introduced a new "blocks" command to the CLI, providing usage reports grouped by 5-hour billing windows.
Added detailed reporting for active and recent 5-hour blocks, including projections, token limits, and cost calculations.
Enhanced output options with JSON formatting and customizable display modes.


Documentation

Updated the README with a comprehensive section on the new 5-hour blocks report, including usage examples and feature descriptions.

preserving the existing CLI functionality and maintaining type safety.

test: add tests for loadFiveHourBlockData function

Add comprehensive test coverage for the loadFiveHourBlockData function in data-loader.ts:
- Empty file handling
- Five-hour block identification and aggregation
- Cost calculation mode support (auto/calculate/display)
- Date range filtering (since/until parameters)
- Sort order handling (asc/desc)
- Deduplication of duplicate entries
- Invalid JSON line handling

Tests ensure the function properly loads JSONL files, processes them into
five-hour blocks using the identifyFiveHourBlocks utility, and applies
all filtering and sorting options correctly.

test: add comprehensive tests for five-hour-blocks utility functions

- projectBlockUsage: Tests usage projection based on burn rate
- filterRecentBlocks: Tests filtering by time range and active status

- Empty entries
- Gap blocks between sessions
- Different models in same block
- Null cost values
- Cache token handling
- Deduplication scenarios

nodes.message:
fix(five-hour-blocks): remove premature rounding of tokensPerMinute

Remove Math.round() from tokensPerMinute calculation in burnRate function to prevent
accuracy loss in projectBlockUsage calculations. The premature rounding was causing
inflated/deflated projections for long remaining time windows.

Keep tokensPerMinute as raw float for internal calculations and defer rounding
to display formatting only.

nodes.message:
feat(blocks): implement responsive terminal width handling

- Replace basic cli-table3 with ResponsiveTable for terminal width awareness
- Add compact date formatting for narrow terminals (< 120 columns)
- Implement abbreviated model name formatting like other commands
- Support complex table objects with content and hAlign properties
- Add terminal width detection and conditional compact formatting
- Maintain compatibility with existing projected/remaining row structure
- Enable word wrapping and responsive column sizing for better narrow terminal display

Fixes terminal display issues when using blocks command on narrow terminals
where model names and date information would cause table overflow and poor
readability. Now uses the same responsive table system as other commands.

nodes.message:
fix(five-hour-blocks): handle non-positive duration in burn rate calculation

Change strict equality check from === 0 to <= 0 to handle edge cases where
durationMinutes might be negative due to closely timestamped or misordered
entries. This prevents division by zero or negative values and ensures
proper null return for invalid duration scenarios.

nodes.message:
fix(five-hour-blocks): preserve precision in costPerHour calculations

Remove rounding of costPerHour in calculateBurnRate() to maintain precision
for downstream calculations in projectBlockUsage(). The costPerHour value
is used for calculating projectedAdditionalCost, where premature rounding
can introduce cumulative errors. Display formatting is already handled
by formatCurrency() at the presentation layer.

This change ensures accurate cost projections for active blocks while
keeping the user-facing display properly formatted.

nodes.message:
fix(blocks): use comma-separated model names to prevent table layout issues

Changed formatModels function to use comma separation instead of newlines
when displaying multiple model names in the blocks table. This prevents
table rows from being split across multiple lines, maintaining proper
column alignment and improving readability.

The change affects only the visual presentation - functionality remains
the same. Model names are now displayed as:
"claude-opus-4-20250514, <synthetic>, claude-sonnet-4-20250514"
instead of being split across separate lines.

nodes.message: chore: release v9.0.1

docs: clarify offline mode only supports Claude models in CLI help

Update the description for the --offline/-O flag in shared-args.internal.ts
to explicitly mention that cached pricing data is only available for Claude
models. This ensures users understand the limitation when using the help
command or documentation.

docs: add missing documentation for offline mode and responsive tables

Add documentation for two features introduced between v0.8.0 and v9.0.0:

1. Offline Mode (--offline/-O flag):
   - Allows running the tool without network connectivity
   - Uses pre-cached pricing data fetched at build time
   - Only supports Claude models (not other LLM providers)
   - Available for daily, monthly, and session commands
   - Added to Features section and all command examples
   - Includes short alias -O for convenience

2. Responsive Terminal Width Support:
   - Tables automatically adjust to narrow terminal widths
   - Implements intelligent word wrapping for long content
   - Prevents table layout disruption in constrained environments
   - Added to Features section highlighting improved display capabilities

These features enhance usability in offline environments and on devices
with limited screen width, making the tool more versatile and accessible.
chore: release v9.0.0

fix: implement responsive table layout for narrow terminals

nodes.bodyText:
Summary


Fixes issue #81: Narrow terminal widths disrupt table layout
Implements ResponsiveTable utility class that wraps cli-table3 with dynamic column width calculation
Uses string-width library for accurate character width measurement (handles ANSI, emoji, full-width characters)
Provides conditional date formatting that uses compact format (year with line break) when space is constrained
Replaces manual separator rows with empty rows for cleaner visual separation before totals

Key Features

Dynamic Width Calculation: Automatically adjusts column widths based on terminal width and content
Content-First Approach: Uses actual content width to determine optimal column sizing
Intelligent Resizing: Applies minimum width constraints while scaling down when needed
Conditional Date Formatting: Shows full date when space available, compact format when constrained
String-Width Integration: Proper width calculation for colored text, emojis, and multi-byte characters
Graceful Separator Handling: Skips separator rows to let cli-table3 handle borders automatically

Test Plan

 Test with various terminal widths (narrow: 80 cols, wide: 120+ cols)
 Verify no content truncation when sufficient width available
 Confirm conditional date formatting works correctly
 Test with colored output and special characters
 Run full test suite to ensure no regressions
 Verify linting and type checking passes

nodes.message:
fix: implement responsive table layout for narrow terminals

Resolves #81 by adding proper responsive table support that prevents
table layout disruption in narrow terminal widths.

Changes:
- Add ResponsiveTable utility class using cli-table3 built-in wordWrap feature
- Implement dynamic column width calculation based on terminal width
- Add intelligent column width allocation (wider for text, narrower for numbers)
- Replace cli-table3 usage in daily, monthly, and session commands
- Update pushBreakdownRows to work with new table interface
- Maintain existing visual styling and user experience

Features:
- Automatic text wrapping at word boundaries for long content
- Proportional column width distribution with minimum width guarantees
- Special handling for Models column which tends to have longer text
- Responsive behavior that adapts to any terminal width

Technical details:
- Uses cli-table3 wordWrap: true and colWidths options
- Calculates available width after accounting for table borders/separators
- Applies different width multipliers based on column content type
- Preserves all existing table styling (colors, alignment, etc.)
